case_id: 2024-08-12_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: Artists allege defendants used AI image generator Stable Diffusion, trained on copyrighted artworks without permission, to create images mimicking their styles, raising questions about AI training as copyright infringement.
ai_presence: The case centers on an AI software known as Stable Diffusion, an image-generating model allegedly trained on copyrighted artworks without permission. Plaintiffs claim this AI can produce images that imitate their artistic styles. Defendants include companies associated with AI image generation and related services, such as Stability AI and Midjourney, which develop and operate AI models, and DeviantArt, which allegedly integrated such AI tools. The court’s analysis addresses whether using copyrighted artworks to train AI models like Stable Diffusion constitutes direct copyright infringement and evaluates related claims, including those under the DMCA, in the context of AI training and output.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual visual artists bringing copyright lawsuit
parties.defendant_description: AI companies and platform allegedly using artworks

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on use of plaintiffs’ artworks to train Stable Diffusion and generate images imitating their styles.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq. (direct infringement of exclusive rights in copyrighted works).
claims.outcome: Motions to dismiss denied in part; direct copyright infringement claims allowed to proceed against all defendants.

claims.claim: Violation of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act for removal or alteration of copyright management information related to plaintiffs’ artworks used in AI training or outputs.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA), 17 U.S.C. § 1202.
claims.outcome: DMCA claims dismissed with prejudice for failure to meet statutory pleading requirements; not allowed to be repleaded.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on defendants’ alleged benefit from using plaintiffs’ artworks without permission to develop and profit from AI tools and services.
claims.legal_basis: State-law unjust enrichment (potentially preempted by the Copyright Act).
claims.outcome: Unjust enrichment claims dismissed with leave to amend due to possible Copyright Act preemption and insufficient allegations.

defenses.defense: Challenge to sufficiency of copyright infringement allegations, arguing that use of artworks to train AI and generate images does not state a plausible claim of direct infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) failure to state a claim; interpretation of rights under the Copyright Act.

defenses.defense: Argument that DMCA claims are deficient because plaintiffs did not adequately allege removal or alteration of copyright management information with the required scienter and causal connection to infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory requirements under 17 U.S.C. § 1202 and Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Contention that unjust enrichment claims are preempted by the Copyright Act and otherwise inadequately pled as duplicative of copyright claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act preemption doctrine and Rule 12(b)(6) failure to state a distinct state-law claim.

case_id: 2023-10-30_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: Case centers on training and use of AI image generator Stable Diffusion on artists’ copyrighted works without permission.
ai_presence: The case involves defendants’ AI software product, Stable Diffusion, an image-generating artificial intelligence model. Plaintiffs allege that Stable Diffusion was trained on their copyrighted artworks without permission, that the model contains “compressed copies” of training images, and that its outputs may constitute infringing or derivative works. The court analyzes whether using copyrighted images to train an AI model, and the functioning of that AI system, can constitute direct or secondary copyright infringement or violations of the DMCA and related rights.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual visual artists bringing class action
parties.defendant_description: AI and online art platforms, image-generation companies

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on use of plaintiffs’ artworks to train Stable Diffusion and related AI systems without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – direct infringement of exclusive rights in copyrighted works.
claims.outcome: Only Sarah Andersen’s direct copyright infringement claim against Stability AI was allowed to proceed; all other plaintiffs’ direct infringement claims and all direct infringement claims against DeviantArt and Midjourney were dismissed with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Secondary copyright infringement (contributory and/or vicarious) arising from defendants’ alleged facilitation and exploitation of infringing uses of plaintiffs’ works through Stable Diffusion and related services.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – secondary liability doctrines (contributory and vicarious infringement).
claims.outcome: Secondary copyright infringement claims were dismissed for insufficiently specific and implausible allegations, with leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Creation and distribution of infringing derivative works by generating images via Stable Diffusion that allegedly are based on and derived from plaintiffs’ copyrighted artworks and styles.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – exclusive right to prepare derivative works.
claims.outcome: Derivative work–based infringement theories were dismissed as inadequately pleaded and implausible on the current allegations, with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Violation of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) for removal or alteration of copyright management information in connection with training Stable Diffusion and distributing outputs.
claims.legal_basis: DMCA, including 17 U.S.C. § 1202 regarding copyright management information.
claims.outcome: DMCA claims were dismissed due to lack of specific factual allegations tying defendants’ conduct to removal or alteration of copyright management information, with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Other related copyright and state-law claims (including class-wide claims) premised on alleged unauthorized copying, storage, and use of plaintiffs’ images within the Stable Diffusion model as “compressed copies.”
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act and various state-law theories (e.g., unfair competition or similar), as framed in the complaint.
claims.outcome: These additional claims were dismissed because the court found the “compressed copies” theory and related allegations insufficiently specific and implausible as pleaded, but granted plaintiffs leave to amend to clarify and support their theories.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to plead specific instances of copying or concrete facts showing that Stable Diffusion contains or reproduces their works, rendering the infringement allegations implausible.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8 and the plausibility requirement of Twombly/Iqbal.

defenses.defense: Allegations that Stable Diffusion contains “compressed copies” of training images are speculative and not supported by factual detail about how the AI model technically operates.
defenses.legal_basis: Plausibility standard under Twombly/Iqbal; requirement for non-conclusory factual allegations.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs did not adequately allege that outputs from Stable Diffusion are substantially similar to, or derivative of, their specific copyrighted works.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright infringement elements requiring copying of protected expression and substantial similarity or derivative work status.

defenses.defense: DMCA claims lack specific allegations that defendants removed or altered copyright management information from plaintiffs’ works or distributed works knowing such information was removed.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory requirements of 17 U.S.C. § 1202 for DMCA CMI claims and federal pleading standards.

defenses.defense: Claims against DeviantArt and Midjourney are insufficiently tied to concrete infringing acts or specific uses of plaintiffs’ works, failing to state a plausible claim for direct or secondary liability.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act liability standards and Rule 12(b)(6) failure-to-state-a-claim standard.

case_id: 2025-03-19_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over alleged unauthorized use of artists’ works to train the generative AI model Stable Diffusion, raising copyright and discovery issues involving AI training data and systems.
ai_presence: The case involves “a group of visual artists suing five companies, including Stability AI, for allegedly using their artworks without permission to train a generative AI model, Stable Diffusion.” The summary explains that the artworks were allegedly used “to train a generative AI model, Stable Diffusion,” and describes the matter as “a complex case involving AI technologies.” The court’s decision concerns discovery protocols in litigation about this AI training and use of Stable Diffusion.

parties.plaintiff_description: Group of individual visual artists
parties.defendant_description: Multiple AI and technology companies

claims.claim: Unauthorized use of plaintiffs’ artworks to train the Stable Diffusion generative AI model.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under U.S. copyright law (alleged).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this order; court only addresses discovery and ESI protocol issues.

claims.claim: Widespread copying and exploitation of plaintiffs’ copyrighted artworks through AI training without permission.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement and related intellectual property claims (alleged).
claims.outcome: Substantive outcome not decided; court’s ruling is limited to managing discovery, including ESI and depositions.

defenses.defense: Discovery in this complex AI case should be limited to reduce burden, including limits on ESI scope and number of depositions.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure proportionality and burden principles governing discovery.

case_id: 2024-02-12_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03223_Tremblay et al v. OpenAI_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Tremblay et al. v. OpenAI, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over training and operation of OpenAI’s ChatGPT AI language models on copyrighted books without authorization.
ai_presence: The case centers on OpenAI’s development and deployment of ChatGPT, described as an AI language model trained on large amounts of text, including allegedly copyrighted books. Plaintiffs allege that OpenAI used their copyrighted works, without consent or compensation, as training data for its AI models. The complaint asserts that the AI training process involved copying entire books into OpenAI’s systems so that the models could learn patterns of language and generate human‑like text. Plaintiffs claim that this use of their works to train AI constitutes direct copyright infringement and supports an unfair competition claim under California’s Unfair Competition Law. The court’s order on the motion to dismiss repeatedly refers to ChatGPT and OpenAI’s AI language models, analyzing whether the ingestion of copyrighted books to train these AI systems, and the subsequent operation of those systems, can give rise to liability for direct copyright infringement and unfair business practices. The court ultimately allows the direct copyright infringement claim tied to AI training and use to proceed, and finds that the alleged use of copyrighted books to build and commercialize AI models may support a claim under the “unfair” prong of the UCL, while dismissing other AI‑related theories such as vicarious infringement, DMCA violations, negligence, and unjust enrichment with leave to amend.

parties.plaintiff_description: Authors bringing putative class action
parties.defendant_description: AI company defendants operating ChatGPT models

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on using plaintiffs’ copyrighted books to train OpenAI’s AI language models (including ChatGPT) without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq. (direct infringement).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to this claim; the claim is allowed to proceed at the pleading stage.

claims.claim: Vicarious copyright infringement arising from OpenAI’s alleged control over and financial benefit from infringing uses of plaintiffs’ works by its AI models and users.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq. (vicarious infringement doctrine).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on the motion to dismiss for insufficient allegations; plaintiffs granted leave to amend to add more specific supporting facts.

claims.claim: Violation of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) for allegedly removing or altering copyright management information associated with plaintiffs’ works during ingestion and training of the AI models.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 1202.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on the motion to dismiss for lack of sufficient factual detail; plaintiffs granted leave to amend to attempt to cure deficiencies.

claims.claim: Negligence based on OpenAI’s alleged failure to exercise reasonable care in acquiring, handling, and using copyrighted books to train its AI models, and in preventing resulting harms to authors.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law negligence (duty, breach, causation, damages).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on the motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim; plaintiffs granted leave to amend with additional supporting allegations.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on OpenAI’s alleged retention of benefits from using plaintiffs’ copyrighted works to develop and commercialize AI models without compensating the authors.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law unjust enrichment / restitution principles.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on the motion to dismiss as not adequately pleaded; plaintiffs granted leave to amend to provide more detailed factual support.

claims.claim: Unfair competition under California’s Unfair Competition Law (UCL) based on allegedly unfair business practices in using copyrighted books without authorization to train and profit from AI models.
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law, Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 et seq., particularly the “unfair” prong.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; the court found the allegations could support a claim under the “unfair” prong of the UCL, allowing that theory to proceed while dismissing other UCL theories to the extent they overlapped with dismissed claims, with leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Challenge to sufficiency of the copyright infringement allegations, arguing that plaintiffs failed to plausibly allege actionable copying or infringing outputs from the AI models.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) (failure to state a claim) and substantive copyright law standards for pleading infringement.

defenses.defense: Challenge to vicarious copyright infringement, asserting plaintiffs did not adequately allege OpenAI’s right and ability to supervise specific infringing acts or a direct financial benefit from particular infringements.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); vicarious copyright infringement doctrine requiring control and direct financial benefit.

defenses.defense: Challenge to DMCA claims, contending plaintiffs did not plead specific facts showing removal or alteration of copyright management information with the requisite scienter.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); 17 U.S.C. § 1202 requirements for removal/alteration of copyright management information and knowledge/intent elements.

defenses.defense: Challenge to negligence claim, arguing no cognizable duty of care and that the claim is preempted or otherwise not viable under state law.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); state negligence principles and potential preemption by federal copyright law.

defenses.defense: Challenge to unjust enrichment claim, asserting it is inadequately pleaded and/or duplicative of copyright claims and preempted by federal law.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); state unjust enrichment law and federal copyright preemption doctrine.

defenses.defense: Challenge to UCL claim, arguing plaintiffs failed to allege unlawful, unfair, or fraudulent conduct beyond what is covered by copyright law or otherwise insufficient under the UCL standards.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); California Unfair Competition Law standards for “unlawful,” “unfair,” and “fraudulent” prongs.

case_id: 2019-11-21_USCOURTS-cand-3_19-cv-03132_UAB _Planner5D_ v. Meta Platforms_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: UAB Planner5D v. Meta Platforms, Inc. (Facebook, Inc.) et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges defendants scraped its 3D design dataset to develop and train AI-driven scene recognition and related computer vision technologies.
ai_presence: The summary describes that defendants allegedly used automated “scraping” to download Planner 5D’s proprietary 3D design data, which is characterized as crucial for AI-driven scene recognition technology. The data was allegedly used in connection with artificial intelligence and machine learning research and development, including training algorithms for scene recognition and related computer vision tasks.

parties.plaintiff_description: Online 3D interior design software company
parties.defendant_name: Meta Platforms, Inc.; Princeton University, et al.
parties.defendant_description: Technology company and university AI research collaborators

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged unauthorized copying and use of Planner 5D’s 3D design objects and scenes dataset via automated scraping.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. Copyright Act, including 17 U.S.C. § 501 and registration requirements under 17 U.S.C. § 411(a).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court held plaintiff failed to sufficiently allege valid copyright registrations, originality, and specific infringing acts, but granted leave to amend the complaint.

claims.claim: Contributory and/or vicarious copyright infringement arising from defendants’ alleged use, distribution, or facilitation of use of the scraped 3D dataset in AI research and related projects.
claims.legal_basis: Secondary liability doctrines under the U.S. Copyright Act (contributory and vicarious infringement).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice along with primary copyright claims; court found underlying direct infringement insufficiently pled, but allowed leave to amend.

claims.claim: Trade secret misappropriation based on alleged taking and use of Planner 5D’s proprietary 3D design library and dataset.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA), 18 U.S.C. § 1836 et seq., and parallel state trade secret law (e.g., California Uniform Trade Secrets Act).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court held plaintiff did not adequately allege reasonable measures to maintain secrecy or sufficiently plead improper acquisition, use, or disclosure, but granted leave to amend.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and related state-law business torts premised on the alleged scraping and use of Planner 5D’s data to develop competing or related AI technologies.
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition law (e.g., California Unfair Competition Law, Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200, and similar doctrines).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court found these claims rose or fell with the inadequately pled copyright and trade secret theories, but allowed leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for copyright infringement because plaintiff did not adequately allege valid copyright registrations, originality of the works, or specific infringing acts tied to registered works.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); requirements of the U.S. Copyright Act including 17 U.S.C. §§ 102, 103, 411(a), and case law on pleading copyright infringement.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for trade secret misappropriation because plaintiff did not plausibly allege that the information qualified as a trade secret or that reasonable measures were taken to maintain its secrecy.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); Defend Trade Secrets Act, 18 U.S.C. § 1839(3), and analogous state trade secret statutes requiring secrecy and reasonable protective measures.

defenses.defense: No plausible allegation of improper acquisition, use, or disclosure of trade secrets, because the data was allegedly accessible via the public-facing website and the complaint did not sufficiently describe wrongful means.
defenses.legal_basis: DTSA and state trade secret law standards for “misappropriation,” and Rule 12(b)(6) pleading requirements.

defenses.defense: Derivative state-law and unfair competition claims fail because they are premised on inadequately pled copyright and trade secret violations.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6); preemption and dependency principles under the Copyright Act and state unfair competition doctrines.

case_id: 2025-06-25_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03417_Kadrey et al v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Kadrey et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over using books as training data for Meta’s Llama generative AI models; court analyzes whether training large language models on copyrighted works is fair use.
ai_presence: The case centers on Meta’s development and use of generative AI models, specifically its Llama large language models. Plaintiffs alleged that Meta used their copyrighted books as training data to develop these AI models. The court describes Meta’s use of the books as training data for Llama, a large language model that learns statistical relationships between words and passages to generate new text. The opinion explains that the AI system does not reproduce the plaintiffs’ books verbatim as outputs, but instead uses them in the training process to improve the model’s ability to generate language. The court ultimately concludes that Meta’s use of the plaintiffs’ works to train its generative AI models is highly transformative and, on the record presented, constitutes fair use because plaintiffs did not provide sufficient evidence of market harm from the AI training use.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual authors of copyrighted literary works
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating social media and AI platforms

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Meta’s use of plaintiffs’ books as training data for its Llama large language models.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 106 (exclusive rights in copyrighted works), alleging unauthorized reproduction and use of the works in AI training.
claims.outcome: Court granted Meta’s motion for partial summary judgment, holding that Meta’s use of the works to train its Llama models was protected as fair use; infringement claim failed as to that training use.

claims.claim: Derivative works / unfair exploitation theory that outputs of the Llama models unlawfully draw on plaintiffs’ books.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 106(2) (exclusive right to prepare derivative works), premised on the idea that Llama outputs are infringing derivatives of plaintiffs’ books.
claims.outcome: Court rejected the theory on summary judgment because plaintiffs did not present evidence that Llama outputs reproduced protectable expression from their books; Meta prevailed on this aspect of the infringement claim.

claims.claim: Market harm / lost licensing revenue theory that Meta’s AI training use supplanted or harmed the market for licensing plaintiffs’ works for AI training.
claims.legal_basis: Fourth fair-use factor under 17 U.S.C. § 107 (effect of the use upon the potential market for or value of the copyrighted work).
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiffs failed to provide sufficient evidence of actual or likely market harm from Meta’s AI training use; this failure weighed decisively in favor of fair use and supported granting summary judgment for Meta.

defenses.defense: Fair use: Meta’s use of plaintiffs’ books to train its Llama large language models is a transformative use that does not cause cognizable market harm.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 107 (fair use doctrine), including analysis of purpose and character of the use, nature of the works, amount used, and effect on the market.

defenses.defense: Transformative use: Training a generative AI model on copyrighted books to learn statistical relationships between words is fundamentally different from the original expressive purpose of the books.
defenses.legal_basis: Case law interpreting § 107, including transformative-use jurisprudence (e.g., use for data analysis or machine learning distinct from expressive consumption).

defenses.defense: Lack of evidence of infringing outputs: Plaintiffs did not show that Llama’s outputs reproduce protectable expression from their books.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright infringement elements requiring substantial similarity and copying of protectable expression; absence of proof defeats derivative-work and output-based infringement theories.

defenses.defense: No demonstrated market substitution: Plaintiffs failed to show that Meta’s AI training use or Llama outputs supplanted the market for their books or for licensing their works for AI training.
defenses.legal_basis: Fourth factor of fair use under 17 U.S.C. § 107, requiring evidence of actual or likely market harm or usurpation of traditional, reasonable, or likely-to-develop markets.

case_id: 2025-07-30_USCOURTS-cand-5_23-cv-04534_Sage Global Services Limited et al v. 4th Paradigm _Beijing_ Technology Co._ Ltd..pdf
case_name: Sage Global Services Limited et al. v. 4th Paradigm (Beijing) Technology Co., Ltd.
ai_relevance: Dispute over use of SAGE mark in connection with software and AI products allegedly offered by defendant, including branding of AI-related technology and services.
ai_presence: The summary states that the alleged trademark infringement was "in connection with software and AI products using the SAGE mark," indicating that the defendant’s offerings included AI products branded with the SAGE name.

parties.plaintiff_name: Sage Global Services Limited; Sage Software, Inc.
parties.plaintiff_description: Affiliated software and technology companies asserting SAGE trademarks.
parties.defendant_description: Chinese technology company offering software and AI products.

claims.claim: Trademark infringement based on defendant’s use of the SAGE mark in connection with software and AI products.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trademark law (e.g., Lanham Act) protecting the SAGE mark against unauthorized use likely to cause confusion.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without reaching merits because the court found it lacked personal jurisdiction over the defendant due to insufficient minimum contacts with California and the United States.

claims.claim: Related trademark and unfair competition claims arising from alleged misuse of the SAGE brand in commerce (e.g., false designation of origin/unfair competition).
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state unfair competition and false designation of origin provisions associated with trademark rights.
claims.outcome: Also dismissed on jurisdictional grounds; court declined to exercise jurisdiction over defendant and did not adjudicate substantive liability.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in California and the United States because defendant’s contacts with the forum were insufficient.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process requirements for personal jurisdiction, including lack of general and specific jurisdiction based on insufficient minimum contacts with the forum.

case_id: 2024-12-06_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03417_Kadrey et al v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Kadrey et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege Meta used copyrighted books to train Llama AI models without permission, challenging AI training datasets and related practices.
ai_presence: The opinion describes a lawsuit where plaintiffs claim Meta Platforms, Inc. used copyrighted books without authorization to train its large language models, including Llama. The court notes that Meta’s Llama AI models were trained on datasets that allegedly contained plaintiffs’ copyrighted works. Discovery disputes center on Meta’s dataset usage, the composition and sources of training data for the Llama models (including Llama 5), and Meta’s responses to requests for admission and production about which copyrighted books were included in the AI training corpora, how they were obtained, and whether Meta had permission. The court orders Meta to amend certain discovery responses, expand definitions to include Llama 5, and provide full documents rather than summaries regarding the datasets and training of its Llama AI systems.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual authors and rights holders
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating social and AI platforms

claims.claim: Meta used plaintiffs’ copyrighted books without permission to train its Llama large language models.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under federal copyright law (unauthorized reproduction and use in training datasets).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this discovery order; litigation continues. The court only ruled on related discovery disputes.

claims.claim: Meta’s use of copyrighted books in AI training datasets exceeded any license or implied authorization granted to Meta.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement and breach of license/terms theories (scope-of-license and overuse of works).
claims.outcome: Substantive claim not decided; in this order, the court compelled Meta to provide more complete discovery about dataset composition and licensing, granting the motion to compel in part and denying it in part.

claims.claim: Meta failed to adequately respond to requests for admission regarding its use of copyrighted works and the training of Llama models, including Llama 5.
claims.legal_basis: Federal discovery rules (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 and 36) requiring complete, non-evasive responses to requests for admission.
claims.outcome: Court granted in part and denied in part plaintiffs’ motion to compel, ordering Meta to amend and clarify several RFA responses, including expanding definitions to cover Llama 5.

claims.claim: Meta failed to adequately produce documents and information about the datasets and sources used to train its Llama AI models, instead providing summaries or limited disclosures.
claims.legal_basis: Federal discovery rules (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 and 34) governing scope and sufficiency of document production.
claims.outcome: Court granted in part and denied in part plaintiffs’ motion to compel production, requiring Meta to produce full documents rather than summaries for certain requests and to provide more specific information about training datasets where the requests were found relevant and proportional.

defenses.defense: Meta’s existing responses to requests for admission were sufficient, non-evasive, and compliant with Rule 36.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal discovery standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 and 36; objections based on burden, ambiguity, and adequacy of prior responses.

defenses.defense: Certain requested discovery about Llama models and training datasets was irrelevant, overbroad, or disproportionate to the needs of the case.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(1) proportionality and relevance limits on discovery.

defenses.defense: Meta could provide summaries or limited disclosures instead of full underlying documents for some dataset-related requests.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 34 and general discovery principles allowing reasonable limits on production where full production is unduly burdensome or cumulative.

case_id: 2025-08-19_USCOURTS-ded-1_24-cv-01092_Hangzhou Jicai Procurement Co._ Ltd et al v. Anaconda_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Hangzhou Jicai Procurement Co., Ltd. et al. v. Anaconda, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute concerns contracts for Anaconda’s AI technology software and related use.
ai_presence: The summary states the case concerns “the validity and breach of contracts related to Anaconda's AI technology software.” This indicates that Anaconda’s AI technology software is central to the underlying contractual relationships and the requested declaratory judgment.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate entities affiliated with Alibaba Group
parties.defendant_description: Technology company providing AI software tools

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that the Anaconda Agreements are valid and/or have not been breached by Jicai and AliCloud, and that they are not liable under those contracts.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act; contract law principles regarding validity and breach of the Anaconda Agreements.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; court held plaintiffs had no subject matter jurisdiction to pursue declaratory relief.

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment clarifying that Anaconda’s pending Texas breach of contract litigation against other Alibaba entities does not create liability or legal exposure for Jicai and AliCloud under the Anaconda Agreements.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act; Article III case-or-controversy requirement; contract interpretation of Anaconda Agreements.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing because plaintiffs were not parties to the Texas suit and did not show an immediate, substantial threat of injury.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack Article III standing because they are not parties to the Texas breach of contract action and have not shown adverse legal interests or a real and immediate threat of injury from that litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III case-or-controversy requirement; standing doctrine for declaratory judgment actions.

defenses.defense: Declaratory judgment is improper because there is no justiciable controversy between Anaconda and Jicai/AliCloud regarding the Anaconda Agreements at this time.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act requirements; justiciability and ripeness doctrines.

case_id: 2025-01-08_USCOURTS-cand-4_24-cv-01454_Nazemian et al v. NVIDIA Corporation.pdf
case_name: Nazemian et al. v. NVIDIA Corporation (consolidated with Dubus v. NVIDIA Inc.)
ai_relevance: Dispute involves protection of proprietary AI and machine learning source code and technical materials during discovery and court filings.
ai_presence: The opinion describes a stipulated protective order governing “Confidential” and “Highly Confidential” material, specifically including proprietary technology related to artificial intelligence and machine learning. It covers “source code for machine learning models and AI systems,” and other sensitive technical information. The order sets rules for how such AI-related proprietary information is designated, produced, accessed, and filed under seal, and incorporates procedures under U.S. civil rules for handling this AI-related material in litigation.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individuals bringing civil actions against NVIDIA
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation and AI hardware/software developer

claims.claim: Request for court protection of confidential and highly confidential discovery materials, including AI and machine-learning source code and technical information, from public disclosure or misuse during litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(c) (protective orders) and parties’ stipulated agreement regarding confidentiality in discovery.
claims.outcome: Granted; the court entered the stipulated protective order setting detailed procedures for designating, using, and filing confidential and highly confidential material.

defenses.defense: Need to limit disclosure and tightly control access to proprietary AI, machine-learning source code, and other trade-secret technical information to prevent competitive harm and unauthorized use.
defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret and proprietary information protections, and good cause standard under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) for issuance of protective orders.

case_id: 2025-07-15_USCOURTS-ded-1_25-cv-00201_Aon Re_ Inc. v. Zesty.ai_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Aon Re, Inc. v. Zesty.ai, Inc.
ai_relevance: Patents cover machine-learning models that analyze aerial property images to assess risk; dispute centers on whether this ML-based method is patent-eligible under 35 U.S.C. § 101.
ai_presence: The case summary states the patents "use machine learning to analyze aerial photographs of properties to assess risk." It further explains that Zesty.AI argued the patents "only implement the abstract idea of risk assessment with generic machine learning." The court held the patents recite "a specific technological method involving two independently trained machine learning classifiers that analyze different aspects of a property," concluding this arrangement of classifiers is a patent-eligible technological solution rather than a generalized use of technology.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate plaintiff, insurance and risk services
parties.defendant_description: Corporate defendant, AI property analytics

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on use of Aon’s patented machine-learning methods for analyzing aerial property images to assess risk.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) and related U.S. patent laws covering asserted patents that employ machine learning classifiers for property risk assessment.
claims.outcome: At motion-to-dismiss stage, court rejected defendant’s § 101 invalidity challenge and denied motion to dismiss; infringement claim proceeds.

claims.claim: Validity of Aon’s patents on machine-learning-based property risk assessment against challenge that they are directed to an abstract idea and thus patent-ineligible.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (patent-eligible subject matter; abstract idea doctrine under Alice/Mayo framework).
claims.outcome: Court held the asserted patents are not directed to an abstract idea because they recite a specific technological method using two independently trained machine-learning classifiers analyzing different property aspects; patents deemed patent-eligible at this stage and motion to dismiss denied.

defenses.defense: The asserted patents are invalid because they are directed to the abstract idea of risk assessment implemented with generic machine learning and therefore claim patent-ineligible subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; abstract idea doctrine under Alice/Mayo two-step framework.

case_id: 2022-09-21_USCOURTS-cand-3_22-cv-02366_Shared Partnership v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Shared Partnership v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Canadian online content creator and publisher business
parties.defendant_description: Social media and online advertising technology corporation

claims.claim: Breach of contract for restricting or removing Shared’s access to Facebook advertising and monetization services contrary to agreed terms.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law; alleged violation of Facebook/Meta terms and related agreements.
claims.outcome: Partially dismissed: claims premised on content removal barred by Section 230(c)(1); contract claims based on Meta’s separate procedural obligations allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Breach of contract for failing to provide required notice and adequate explanations for ad rejections and service restrictions.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law; obligations arising from Facebook/Meta terms regarding notice and explanations.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to these aspects; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Breach of contract for failing to comply with contractual payment timing and monetization obligations.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law; payment and monetization provisions in Meta’s terms and related agreements.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to these payment‑related obligations; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Misrepresentation related to how Facebook’s advertising and monetization systems and enforcement would operate, including notice and review processes.
claims.legal_basis: State tort law for misrepresentation/fraudulent or negligent misrepresentation.
claims.outcome: Partially dismissed to the extent based on content removal decisions protected by Section 230(c)(1); portions tied to independent contractual procedural promises allowed to proceed.

defenses.defense: Immunity under Section 230(c)(1) of the Communications Decency Act for decisions to remove or restrict access to content and services on the platform.
defenses.legal_basis: 47 U.S.C. § 230(c)(1) (Communications Decency Act).

defenses.defense: Contractual rights to moderate, restrict, or remove content and advertising under Facebook/Meta terms of service and related policies.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law; enforcement of platform terms of service and advertising policies.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim where alleged duties are inseparable from content moderation decisions covered by Section 230 immunity.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); interpretation of Section 230(c)(1) scope.

case_id: 2022-12-06_USCOURTS-cand-3_20-cv-08570_Klein et al v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Klein et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege Meta used AI and machine-learning-driven tools and algorithms in its social advertising platform to help maintain and exploit monopoly power, contributing to inflated ad prices and exclusion of rivals.
ai_presence: The summary indicates that plaintiffs allege Meta “used a variety of anticompetitive tactics, including integrating artificial intelligence and machine learning models, to maintain its dominance” in the social advertising market, and that the court found “plausible allegations of anticompetitive conduct, which included the use of AI and ML technologies, that merit further examination through litigation.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Class of Facebook advertisers suing under antitrust laws
parties.defendant_description: Social media and digital advertising technology corporation

claims.claim: Meta unlawfully monopolized the social advertising market, leading to inflated ad prices for Facebook advertisers.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act (monopolization) and related federal antitrust principles.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; monopolization claim allowed to proceed to discovery and further litigation.

claims.claim: Meta attempted to monopolize the social advertising market through exclusionary and anticompetitive conduct, including use of AI and machine learning tools to entrench its dominance.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act (attempted monopolization).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; attempted monopolization claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Meta engaged in anticompetitive agreements and practices that unreasonably restrained trade in the social advertising market.
claims.legal_basis: Section 1 of the Sherman Act (unreasonable restraint of trade / anticompetitive agreements).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; Section 1 restraint-of-trade claims allowed to proceed as plausibly alleged.

claims.claim: Meta’s conduct in maintaining and exploiting its dominance in social advertising caused advertisers to pay supracompetitive prices and suffer antitrust injury.
claims.legal_basis: Federal antitrust injury and damages theories under the Sherman Act and Clayton Act (private right of action).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court found plaintiffs plausibly alleged antitrust injury and causation sufficient to proceed.

defenses.defense: The complaint fails to state a claim because plaintiffs have not plausibly alleged monopoly power, anticompetitive conduct, or a properly defined relevant market in social advertising.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); substantive standards under Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act for market definition, monopoly power, and exclusionary conduct.

defenses.defense: Meta’s challenged conduct, including its use of technology and platform design choices, is lawful competition on the merits and procompetitive, not exclusionary or anticompetitive.
defenses.legal_basis: Sherman Act Sections 1 and 2 jurisprudence distinguishing lawful competitive behavior from unlawful exclusionary conduct.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs have not adequately alleged antitrust injury or standing because any harm they suffered is speculative or not caused by Meta’s alleged anticompetitive conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust standing and injury requirements under the Clayton Act § 4 and related federal antitrust case law.

case_id: 2024-12-20_USCOURTS-mad-1_22-cv-10723_In Re Cerence Stockholder Derivative Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Cerence Stockholder Derivative Litigation
ai_relevance: Cerence develops AI-powered virtual assistants for automakers; shareholders challenge directors’ conduct at this AI-focused company.
ai_presence: The summary states Cerence, Inc. is “a company that develops AI-powered virtual assistants for automakers.” This describes the business context in which the alleged misconduct occurred.

parties.plaintiff_description: Shareholder derivative plaintiffs suing on company’s behalf
parties.defendant_description: Corporate officers and directors of Cerence, Inc.

claims.claim: Derivative claim for violations of the Exchange Act
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities law – Exchange Act provisions (e.g., Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5, and related provisions, as typically invoked in derivative securities actions)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for improper forum denied; Exchange Act-based derivative claims may proceed in federal court under the Bylaws’ forum-selection clause.

claims.claim: Breach of fiduciary duty by officers and directors
claims.legal_basis: State corporate law fiduciary duties (duty of care, loyalty, and good faith under Delaware law)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss based on Delaware-only forum-selection clause denied; breach of fiduciary duty derivative claims are allowed to proceed in the current federal forum at this stage.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment arising from alleged misconduct and insider trading
claims.legal_basis: Equitable unjust enrichment under state (Delaware) law
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of proper forum denied; unjust enrichment claim remains pending in federal court.

claims.claim: Insider trading by certain officers and/or directors
claims.legal_basis: State-law derivative insider trading theories and/or federal securities law provisions related to trading on material nonpublic information
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss based on forum-selection arguments denied; insider trading derivative claim may go forward in this federal action.

defenses.defense: Forum-selection clause in the Charter requires all derivative actions to be brought exclusively in Delaware state courts, so this federal case should be dismissed or refiled there.
defenses.legal_basis: Contractual/forum-selection provisions in Cerence’s Charter, interpreted under Delaware corporate and contract law principles.

defenses.defense: The Charter’s Delaware-only forum clause supersedes or controls over any inconsistent Bylaws provision, thereby barring derivative Exchange Act claims in federal court.
defenses.legal_basis: Hierarchy of corporate governance documents (Charter over Bylaws) under Delaware corporate law and contract interpretation doctrines.

case_id: 2025-10-22_USCOURTS-cand-4_25-cv-09081_Pete v. Facebook Data Breach __Transferred to ND_CA__.pdf
case_name: Pete v. Meta Platforms, Inc. (Facebook Data Breach)
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer and data-breach plaintiff
parties.defendant_description: Social media technology corporation, formerly Facebook

claims.claim: Meta is liable for harms arising from a Facebook-related data breach affecting plaintiff’s personal information.
claims.legal_basis: Implied federal and/or state data privacy, negligence, and related data-breach liability theories (exact causes of action not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Substantive merits not decided; case transferred to the Northern District of California for further proceedings.

claims.claim: The case should remain in the Eastern District of Texas and not be transferred to the Northern District of California.
claims.legal_basis: Procedural objection to transfer under 28 U.S.C. § 1631 and interest-of-justice factors; plaintiff argued personal hardship, financial status, and pro se status as reasons to keep venue in Texas.
claims.outcome: Rejected; court overruled plaintiff’s objections and upheld transfer to the Northern District of California.

defenses.defense: The Eastern District of Texas lacks personal jurisdiction over Meta for this dispute.
defenses.legal_basis: Personal jurisdiction principles under the Due Process Clause and federal venue/transfer statutes, including 28 U.S.C. § 1631.

defenses.defense: Transfer to the Northern District of California is proper and in the interest of justice, consistent with Meta’s forum-selection expectations and the locus of relevant conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1631 and interest-of-justice transfer analysis, including convenience, proper forum, and prior agreements tying disputes to California.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s financial hardship and pro se status do not justify retaining the case in an improper forum or blocking transfer.
defenses.legal_basis: General federal transfer and jurisdiction doctrine; equitable and interest-of-justice considerations under 28 U.S.C. § 1631 do not override lack of personal jurisdiction.

case_id: 2025-10-20_USCOURTS-mad-3_23-cv-13196_Demand Dogs_ LLC v. Blair.pdf
case_name: Demand Dogs, LLC v. Blair
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED
ai_presence: The summary notes: “indicating elements of AI involvement limited to his previous duties at Demand Dogs, unrelated to the bourbon-monitoring invention.” No further AI-related technology is described as part of the disputed bourbon-monitoring patent or the claims at issue.

parties.plaintiff_description: Limited liability company business entity
parties.defendant_description: Individual alleged inventor and former associate

claims.claim: Correction of inventorship and recognition of Blair as an inventor of the bourbon-monitoring technology covered by the nonprovisional patent filed by Barrel Proof.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law – claim for correction of inventorship under 35 U.S.C. § 256 and related patent ownership principles.
claims.outcome: Court held Blair stated a sufficient inventorship claim and granted his motion to amend the third-party complaint to assert this claim against Barrel Proof.

claims.claim: Ownership interest in the patented bourbon-monitoring technology and related patent rights allegedly derived from Blair’s original invention.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law and associated state-law ownership principles concerning entitlement to patent rights based on inventorship and contribution to the invention.
claims.outcome: Court found Blair’s allegations of ownership tied to inventorship sufficient at the pleading stage and allowed amendment to add Barrel Proof as a defendant on these theories.

claims.claim: Claims against Barrel Proof as a third-party defendant for wrongfully excluding Blair from the patent and related business opportunities.
claims.legal_basis: Third-party practice under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 14, combined with patent law inventorship/ownership theories and potentially related state-law claims (e.g., unjust enrichment or breach of duty).
claims.outcome: Initial attempt to add Barrel Proof was denied for procedural noncompliance; after Blair corrected the procedural issues, the court granted his renewed motion to amend the third-party complaint to include Barrel Proof.

defenses.defense: Challenge to personal jurisdiction over Barrel Proof, a Tennessee LLC, arguing insufficient contacts with Massachusetts.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process and personal jurisdiction standards under the U.S. Constitution and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2).

defenses.defense: Implicit denial that Blair is an inventor or owner of the patented bourbon-monitoring technology, asserting that the invention belongs to Barrel Proof and/or its principals.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive patent law on inventorship and ownership, contesting Blair’s factual and legal entitlement to be named as an inventor or owner.

case_id: 2025-05-16_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00770_Mobley v. Workday_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Mobley v. Workday, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs challenge Workday’s AI-based applicant screening and recommendation system as discriminatory.
ai_presence: The case summary states that plaintiffs are suing Workday, Inc., alleging that its "AI-based applicant recommendation system" discriminates against job candidates based on age, race, and disability. The court describes a unified discriminatory policy implemented "through Workday’s AI system" that allegedly causes a disparate impact on applicants over forty. The key legal issue is framed as whether "Workday's AI recommendation system" causes a disparate impact on applicants over the age of forty, in violation of the ADEA. The court’s holding notes that Mobley adequately alleged that this AI system impacts applicants over forty in a way suitable for common proof across the proposed collective.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual job applicants, collective representatives
parties.defendant_description: Corporation providing hiring and HR software

claims.claim: Age discrimination via disparate impact from Workday’s AI-based applicant recommendation system against applicants over forty.
claims.legal_basis: Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) – disparate impact theory, collective action under 29 U.S.C. § 216(b).
claims.outcome: Court granted preliminary collective certification for the ADEA age discrimination claim, allowing notice to similarly situated applicants over forty to opt into the lawsuit; merits of liability not yet decided.

claims.claim: Discrimination based on race and disability by Workday’s AI-based applicant recommendation system in screening and recommending job applicants.
claims.legal_basis: Federal anti-discrimination statutes (e.g., Title VII for race; ADA for disability) – disparate impact and/or disparate treatment theories (as alleged in the broader complaint).
claims.outcome: Not resolved at this stage in the described order; the ruling specifically addresses and grants preliminary collective certification only for the age discrimination claim under the ADEA.

defenses.defense: Challenge to collective certification, arguing plaintiffs are not similarly situated and that claims cannot be resolved with common proof.
defenses.legal_basis: Standards for FLSA/ADEA collective actions under 29 U.S.C. § 216(b), requiring a showing that proposed collective members are similarly situated.

defenses.defense: Implicit denial that Workday’s AI-based applicant recommendation system causes unlawful disparate impact on applicants over forty.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive defenses under the ADEA, including contesting existence of disparate impact and/or business necessity and job-relatedness of selection practices.

case_id: 2025-07-14_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute concerns confidential source code and technical materials for AI image generation models; court weighs competitive risk of disclosing these AI-related materials to plaintiffs’ expert.
ai_presence: The case summary describes “source code related to AI image generation models” and identifies Dr. Ben Yanbin Zhao as “an academic researcher specializing in generative AI.” It notes that he “has developed tools that could impact the defendants' AI models,” and that defendants objected to disclosure “over confidentiality risks.” The court’s decision focuses on whether disclosure of “highly confidential materials, including source code related to AI image generation models” to this generative-AI expert “poses a competitive risk that outweighs the plaintiffs' need for his expertise in the litigation.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Group of plaintiffs suing AI companies
parties.defendant_description: AI companies operating image generation models

claims.claim: Plaintiffs seek to have their expert, Dr. Ben Yanbin Zhao, access defendants’ highly confidential materials, including source code for AI image generation models, for purposes of expert analysis in the litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Discovery rights under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and the protective order’s provisions allowing disclosure of confidential materials to qualified experts, subject to court approval.
claims.outcome: Denied. The court held that the competitive risk to defendants from disclosing highly confidential AI source code and related materials to Dr. Zhao outweighs plaintiffs’ need for his expertise, and barred disclosure to him.

defenses.defense: Disclosure of highly confidential AI source code and related technical materials to Dr. Zhao would create an unacceptable risk of competitive harm because he develops tools and research that could affect or be used against defendants’ AI models in the marketplace or future research.
defenses.legal_basis: Protective order standards and Rule 26(c) good cause showing for limiting discovery to prevent competitive harm and misuse of trade secrets and highly confidential information.

case_id: 2025-08-21_USCOURTS-cand-4_24-cv-01454_Nazemian et al v. NVIDIA Corporation.pdf
case_name: Nazemian et al v. NVIDIA Corporation
ai_relevance: Dispute over using copyrighted books in training NVIDIA’s NeMo Megatron large language models built on AI/ML.
ai_presence: Plaintiffs allege that NVIDIA Corporation committed copyright infringement by using their copyrighted books, included in publicly available large datasets like "The Pile," for training its NeMo Megatron large language models. The case involves AI as the dispute centers around the unauthorized use of copyrighted works to train large language models, which are AI-based systems designed to generate and manipulate human language. The court allowed discovery limited to exploring NVIDIA’s use of "The Pile" dataset to train its NeMo Megatron language models, including models beyond the four specifically mentioned in the original complaint, because the term "family" used by NVIDIA was not clearly defined.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual authors alleging copyright infringement
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation developing AI language models

claims.claim: Copyright infringement by using plaintiffs’ books contained in "The Pile" dataset to train NeMo Megatron large language models without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (unauthorized reproduction and use of copyrighted works for AI training).
claims.outcome: On the discovery motion, the court partially granted plaintiffs’ request, allowing discovery into whether NVIDIA used "The Pile" to train any NeMo Megatron models beyond those initially identified; ultimate merits of the copyright claim not yet decided.

defenses.defense: Limitation of discovery to only the four NeMo Megatron models specifically identified in the complaint, based on NVIDIA’s characterization of those models as a single "family."
defenses.legal_basis: Civil procedure and proportional discovery limits under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

case_id: 2022-04-26_USCOURTS-ded-1_20-cv-00613_Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc..pdf
case_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al. v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on ROSS’s AI-powered legal research tool allegedly built using plaintiffs’ content and competing with Westlaw’s search technology.
ai_presence: The case involves ROSS Intelligence’s use of artificial intelligence to develop a legal search tool that competes with Westlaw. ROSS allegedly used AI and machine-learning techniques to train and power its legal research platform, which plaintiffs claim relied on copyrighted Westlaw content. The opinion discusses ROSS’s AI-based legal search product as the competing technology at issue in the antitrust and copyright claims.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate publishers of Westlaw legal research platform
parties.defendant_description: Technology company offering AI legal research tool

claims.claim: Copyright infringement against ROSS for allegedly using and copying Westlaw content to develop and power its competing legal research tool.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (Copyright Act).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this motion; case posture is on ROSS’s counterclaims and plaintiffs’ motion to dismiss them, so the underlying copyright claim continues.

claims.claim: Tortious interference with contractual relations based on ROSS allegedly inducing third parties to breach contracts with plaintiffs related to Westlaw content and services.
claims.legal_basis: State tort law of tortious interference with contract.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this motion; underlying tortious interference claim remains pending while court addresses ROSS’s counterclaims.

claims.claim: Antitrust claim that plaintiffs engaged in unlawful tying by conditioning access to their public law database on the purchase and use of their proprietary legal search tool (Westlaw), thereby foreclosing competition from ROSS’s AI legal search product.
claims.legal_basis: Section 1 of the Sherman Act (unlawful tying agreement and restraint of trade).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; the court allowed ROSS’s tying-based Section 1 claim to proceed, finding ROSS plausibly alleged an unlawful tying arrangement leveraging plaintiffs’ market power.

claims.claim: Monopolization and attempted monopolization based on plaintiffs’ alleged use of tying and other exclusionary conduct to maintain and extend monopoly power in legal research services and public law databases, harming ROSS as a competitor.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act (monopolization and attempted monopolization).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; the court allowed ROSS’s Section 2 claims premised on tying and related exclusionary conduct to proceed as plausibly alleged.

claims.claim: Antitrust claim that plaintiffs’ conduct, including tying and restrictive licensing, constituted unreasonable restraints of trade and exclusion of ROSS from the market for legal research tools.
claims.legal_basis: Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act (restraint of trade and monopolization).
claims.outcome: To the extent based on tying and related exclusionary conduct, the motion to dismiss was denied and those aspects of the claims were allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Unfair competition claim alleging plaintiffs used their market power and restrictive practices to unfairly stifle ROSS’s competing AI legal research product.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state unfair competition law (e.g., Lanham Act or analogous state statutes/common law, as pled in counterclaims).
claims.outcome: To the extent the unfair competition theory overlapped with viable tying and anticompetitive conduct allegations, the court allowed it to proceed; any portion premised solely on sham litigation was dismissed with the sham litigation theory.

claims.claim: Antitrust claim that plaintiffs’ lawsuits against ROSS, including the copyright and tortious interference suit, constituted sham litigation intended to burden and exclude a competitor rather than to vindicate legitimate rights.
claims.legal_basis: Noerr-Pennington doctrine exception; Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act (sham litigation as anticompetitive conduct).
claims.outcome: Dismissed; the court held ROSS failed to plead specific, plausible facts showing the litigation was objectively baseless or a sham, so the sham litigation-based antitrust theory was rejected.

claims.claim: Claim that plaintiffs’ initiation and maintenance of this lawsuit constituted unfair competition and improper use of legal process to suppress a rival’s AI legal research product (sham litigation as unfair competition).
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition law and related doctrines, relying on sham litigation theory.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; because the court found the sham litigation allegations insufficiently specific and implausible, the unfair competition claim premised on sham litigation was also dismissed.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs’ conduct is protected petitioning activity and not actionable anticompetitive behavior because their lawsuit is not a sham under the Noerr-Pennington doctrine.
defenses.legal_basis: Noerr-Pennington immunity under the First Amendment and antitrust law.

defenses.defense: The antitrust counterclaims based on sham litigation fail because ROSS has not plausibly alleged that the underlying copyright and tortious interference claims are objectively baseless or brought in bad faith.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards under Twombly/Iqbal and the sham litigation exception to Noerr-Pennington.

defenses.defense: ROSS’s antitrust and unfair competition counterclaims are inadequately pled and fail to define proper product and geographic markets or to show anticompetitive effects from the alleged tying and licensing practices.
defenses.legal_basis: Sherman Act Sections 1 and 2 requirements for market definition, market power, and anticompetitive effects; federal pleading standards.

defenses.defense: Any tying or bundling of Westlaw’s public law database with its proprietary search tool is lawful product integration and reflects procompetitive business justifications, not unlawful tying.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust law principles permitting product integration and bundled offerings absent coercive or exclusionary effects.

case_id: 2025-02-11_USCOURTS-ded-1_20-cv-00613_Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc..pdf
case_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al. v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
ai_relevance: Defendant used AI-based legal research tool trained on plaintiffs’ Westlaw headnotes, making AI training central to the infringement dispute.
ai_presence: ROSS sought to train its legal AI tool using Westlaw’s copyrighted headnotes, which it obtained indirectly. The case centers on ROSS’s use of AI technology to develop a legal research tool by training it on Thomson Reuters’ proprietary Westlaw headnotes without authorization. The court evaluated whether using Westlaw’s headnotes as training data for an AI-driven legal research system constituted direct copyright infringement and whether such AI-related use could qualify as fair use. The court rejected ROSS’s fair use defense and held that ROSS’s AI training activities infringed Thomson Reuters’ copyrights.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate owner of Westlaw legal research platform
parties.defendant_description: Company developing AI-based legal research tool

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on copying and using Westlaw headnotes to develop and train ROSS’s legal research/AI tool without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq., including exclusive rights to reproduce and prepare derivative works in plaintiffs’ copyrighted Westlaw headnotes.
claims.outcome: Court granted partial summary judgment for Thomson Reuters, holding that ROSS directly infringed Thomson Reuters’ copyrights in the Westlaw headnotes; only the factual issue of whether some copyrights had expired was left for trial.

claims.claim: Declaratory and related relief confirming Thomson Reuters’ ownership and validity of copyrights in Westlaw headnotes.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq., and federal declaratory judgment principles.
claims.outcome: Court accepted that Thomson Reuters owns valid copyrights in the Westlaw headnotes; ROSS’s challenges were rejected except for the limited question of potentially expired copyrights, reserved for trial.

defenses.defense: Fair use – ROSS argued that using Westlaw headnotes to train its AI legal research tool was a transformative, fair use for purposes such as innovation and improving legal research access.
defenses.legal_basis: Fair use doctrine under 17 U.S.C. § 107.

defenses.defense: Challenge to scope/validity of Thomson Reuters’ copyrights, including arguments that some headnotes were not protectable or that certain copyrights had expired.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq., including requirements for originality, protectable expression, and copyright duration.

case_id: 2024-09-27_USCOURTS-ded-1_20-cv-00613_Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc..pdf
case_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al. v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on ROSS’s AI-based legal research/search tool allegedly built using Thomson Reuters’ legal database, and whether Thomson Reuters’ product tying hindered competing AI legal search technologies.
ai_presence: The case summary states that ROSS used Thomson Reuters’ legal database “to develop a competing AI-based search tool.” The dispute concerns ROSS’s “AI-based search tool” for legal research and whether Thomson Reuters’ tying of its legal search tool with its legal database impeded competitors like ROSS from offering similar AI-driven search products.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate provider of legal research databases and tools
parties.defendant_description: Company developing AI-based legal research search tools

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on ROSS’s use of Thomson Reuters’ legal database to develop a competing search tool.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (alleged unauthorized copying/use of proprietary legal database content).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in the provided summary; the summary only describes the disposition of ROSS’s antitrust counterclaims, not the final outcome of Thomson Reuters’ copyright claims.

claims.claim: Antitrust counterclaim alleging illegal tying of Thomson Reuters’ legal search tool with its legal database, excluding competitors like ROSS.
claims.legal_basis: Federal antitrust law on unlawful tying arrangements (e.g., Sherman Act/Clayton Act tying doctrine).
claims.outcome: Court granted summary judgment in favor of Thomson Reuters; ROSS’s tying-based antitrust counterclaims were dismissed for failure to show separate products or properly define relevant markets.

defenses.defense: ROSS challenged Thomson Reuters’ conduct as unlawful tying rather than accepting Thomson Reuters’ product structure as lawful competition.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust tying doctrine requiring proof of separate products and properly defined relevant markets; ROSS failed to meet these elements, leading to summary judgment for Thomson Reuters.

defenses.defense: Thomson Reuters argued that ROSS’s antitrust counterclaims failed because ROSS did not demonstrate that the legal database and legal search tool were separate products or adequately define relevant product and geographic markets.
defenses.legal_basis: Elements of an antitrust tying claim under federal law, including separate products and relevant market definition; relied on summary judgment standards to defeat ROSS’s counterclaims.

case_id: 2024-09-10_USCOURTS-pawd-2_23-cv-01798_ELKIN VALLEY BAPTIST CHURCH v. PNC FINANCIAL SERVICES GROUP_ INC_ et al.pdf
case_name: ELKIN VALLEY BAPTIST CHURCH v. PNC FINANCIAL SERVICES GROUP, INC., et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Religious organization and bank customer
parties.defendant_name: PNC Financial Services Group, Inc.; FNB Corporation
parties.defendant_description: Financial institutions providing banking and wire services

claims.claim: Violation of UCC Article 4A (including § 4A-207) by PNC for executing a wire transfer to a fraudster when the beneficiary name and account number did not match.
claims.legal_basis: Uniform Commercial Code Article 4A, including § 4A-207 (funds transfers).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss by PNC denied; UCC-based claims against PNC allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Common law negligence by PNC for failing to detect and prevent the fraudulent wire transfer despite alleged knowledge or ability to know of mismatched account details.
claims.legal_basis: State common law negligence (duty of reasonable care in handling wire transfers and account information).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss by PNC denied; negligence claim against PNC allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of UCC Article 4A by FNB Corporation relating to its role as the Church’s bank in processing the outgoing wire transfer to the fraudster.
claims.legal_basis: Uniform Commercial Code Article 4A governing funds transfers.
claims.outcome: Not dismissed at this stage; UCC-based claims against FNB remain pending.

claims.claim: Common law negligence by FNB Corporation for its role in processing the fraudulent wire transfer from the Church’s account.
claims.legal_basis: State common law negligence, alleging duties beyond UCC obligations.
claims.outcome: Partially granted FNB’s motion to dismiss; negligence claims against FNB that are not based on conduct outside the wire transfer are dismissed as preempted by the UCC.

defenses.defense: UCC Article 4A preempts common law negligence claims related to the wire transfer, barring negligence liability for conduct covered by the UCC.
defenses.legal_basis: Uniform Commercial Code Article 4A preemption doctrine.

defenses.defense: Banks are entitled to rely on the account number alone for wire transfers and have no duty to verify that the beneficiary name matches the account number absent actual knowledge of a discrepancy.
defenses.legal_basis: UCC § 4A-207 (bank may rely on account number even if name and number identify different persons).

case_id: 2022-09-30_USCOURTS-cand-5_19-cv-04749_Divino Group LLC et al v. Google LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Divino Group LLC et al. v. Google LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on YouTube’s automated, algorithmic systems for moderating and monetizing content.
ai_presence: The case concerns YouTube’s use of automated, algorithmic content moderation and monetization systems that allegedly demonetize, restrict, or limit distribution of LGBTQ+ creators’ videos. Plaintiffs challenge how these algorithms and automated tools classify, restrict, and serve ads on their content, claiming the systems operate in a discriminatory manner. The court’s summary references these systems as part of YouTube’s content moderation practices, which are protected under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act.

parties.plaintiff_description: LGBTQ+ content creators and related entities
parties.defendant_description: Online platform operators of YouTube video service

claims.claim: Discriminatory content moderation and demonetization of LGBTQ+ creators’ videos under the Unruh Civil Rights Act and similar anti-discrimination theories.
claims.legal_basis: California Unruh Civil Rights Act and related anti-discrimination laws; theories that YouTube is a business establishment discriminating based on sexual orientation and related protected characteristics.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held that Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act bars these claims because they challenge YouTube’s content moderation decisions, for which the platform has immunity. Dismissal granted without further leave to amend.

claims.claim: Unlawful restriction, suppression, and unequal treatment of LGBTQ+ content in recommendation, search, and access, framed as wrongful content moderation practices.
claims.legal_basis: Various state and federal statutory and constitutional theories (including free speech–style arguments) asserting that YouTube’s moderation and distribution decisions are unlawful discrimination or censorship.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found YouTube’s decisions about displaying, recommending, or restricting videos fall within Section 230’s protection for publisher functions, so these claims are barred and cannot be further pursued.

claims.claim: Improper demonetization and ad-restriction of LGBTQ+ creators’ videos, allegedly based on sexual orientation and viewpoint, rather than neutral policy enforcement.
claims.legal_basis: State and federal anti-discrimination and unfair business practice theories, including California consumer protection concepts, premised on discriminatory application of monetization policies.
claims.outcome: Dismissed under Section 230 immunity because decisions about monetization and ad placement are treated as publisher functions related to third-party content; dismissal without further leave to amend.

claims.claim: Breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in YouTube’s contractual relationship with creators, based on allegedly arbitrary and discriminatory moderation and monetization decisions.
claims.legal_basis: Common law claim for breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing arising from YouTube’s Terms of Service and related agreements with content creators.
claims.outcome: Partially dismissed but with limited leave to amend; the court allowed plaintiffs a narrow opportunity to replead this specific implied covenant claim, while making clear that any theory that directly attacks content moderation decisions remains constrained by Section 230.

claims.claim: Other contract and quasi-contract claims alleging that YouTube failed to honor promises about fair treatment, visibility, and monetization of content.
claims.legal_basis: Contract and related common law theories (beyond the implied covenant claim) based on alleged promises in Terms of Service, policies, and public statements about how content would be treated.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; the court concluded these claims either failed on the merits or were barred by Section 230 to the extent they sought to impose liability for content moderation and distribution decisions, and they were not granted further leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Section 230 immunity for content moderation decisions, including restricting, demonetizing, or limiting access to user videos.
