defenses.defense: Insufficient allegations that OpenAI’s conduct was unlawful or fraudulent under the UCL, including lack of predicate statutory violations and lack of particularity for any fraud-based theory.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); California Unfair Competition Law, Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200; Rule 9(b) for fraud-based UCL claims.

defenses.defense: Challenge to the sufficiency of plaintiffs’ unfair competition allegations, arguing that OpenAI’s AI training practices are not unfair under the UCL’s balancing or tethering tests.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); California Unfair Competition Law “unfair” prong standards.

case_id: 2019-06-18_USCOURTS-mad-1_18-cv-12336_Conning v. Halpern et al.pdf
case_name: Andrew Scott Conning v. Jack Halpern and CJK Dictionary Institute, Inc.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.defendant_name: Jack Halpern and CJK Dictionary Institute
parties.defendant_description: Individual and Japanese corporation operating dictionary-related business

claims.claim: Defamation
claims.legal_basis: Massachusetts defamation law (state tort law)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied; defamation claim allowed to proceed on the merits.

claims.claim: Tortious interference with advantageous or contractual relations
claims.legal_basis: Massachusetts tort law on interference with contractual or business relations
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied; tortious interference claim allowed to proceed on the merits.

claims.claim: Violation of Massachusetts consumer protection laws
claims.legal_basis: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 93A (unfair or deceptive practices)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied; Chapter 93A claim allowed to proceed on the merits.

claims.claim: Enforcement of an arbitration award
claims.legal_basis: Contract and arbitration law, including enforcement of arbitral awards under applicable statutes
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied; enforcement claim allowed to proceed on the merits.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over the defendants in Massachusetts
defenses.legal_basis: Massachusetts long-arm statute and Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause

defenses.defense: Limited physical presence and operations in Massachusetts
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on exercising specific personal jurisdiction over out-of-state defendants

case_id: 2024-03-29_USCOURTS-mad-1_23-cv-11097_Bulwer v. EchoNous_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Bulwer v. EchoNous, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute concerns work on EchoNous’ AI-enabled ultrasound device, including addressing technical challenges and creating training protocols for the Kosmos system’s artificial intelligence–driven functionality.
ai_presence: The summary describes EchoNous, Inc. as “a company that develops ultrasound software” and specifies that Dr. Bulwer’s services involved “addressing technical challenges and creating training protocols for EchoNous’ AI-enabled ultrasound device, Kosmos.” The court’s description of the underlying work repeatedly references that Kosmos is an “AI-enabled ultrasound device,” and Bulwer’s pre-contract services focused on improving and training this AI-driven system so it could be effectively used in clinical and training settings.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual medical doctor, echocardiography specialist consultant
parties.defendant_description: Corporation developing ultrasound and AI-enabled devices

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment for pre-October 26, 2021 services provided to EchoNous related to the Kosmos AI-enabled ultrasound device.
claims.legal_basis: Common law unjust enrichment under Massachusetts law for benefits conferred without adequate compensation and outside the scope of any enforceable contract.
claims.outcome: Court denied EchoNous’ motion to dismiss; unjust enrichment claim for pre-Agreement services may proceed in Massachusetts.

claims.claim: Quantum meruit for the reasonable value of pre-October 26, 2021 services, including addressing technical challenges and creating training protocols for the Kosmos device.
claims.legal_basis: Common law quantum meruit under Massachusetts law, seeking payment for the reasonable value of services rendered where no contract governs those services.
claims.outcome: Court denied EchoNous’ motion to dismiss; quantum meruit claim for pre-Agreement services may proceed in Massachusetts.

claims.claim: Opposition to enforcement of the Independent Contractor Agreement as a bar to recovery for pre-October 26, 2021 work.
claims.legal_basis: Contract interpretation under state law; argument that the Independent Contractor Agreement did not apply retroactively to services rendered before its effective date.
claims.outcome: Court held that the Agreement did not apply to services provided before October 26, 2021, so it does not preclude Bulwer’s unjust enrichment and quantum meruit claims for that period.

claims.claim: Opposition to transfer of venue to Washington based on the Agreement’s forum selection clause.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law and federal venue/transfer standards (28 U.S.C. § 1404(a)); argument that the forum selection clause does not cover pre-Agreement services and thus should not control venue for these claims.
claims.outcome: Court found the pre-October 26, 2021 services were not sufficiently related to the Agreement to trigger its forum selection clause and denied EchoNous’ motion to transfer the case to Washington, retaining jurisdiction in Massachusetts.

defenses.defense: The Independent Contractor Agreement governs the parties’ relationship and bars quasi-contract claims (unjust enrichment and quantum meruit) for Bulwer’s work, including work performed before October 26, 2021.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law principle that an express contract covering the subject matter precludes recovery under quasi-contract theories such as unjust enrichment and quantum meruit.

defenses.defense: The Agreement’s forum selection clause requires that disputes be litigated in Washington, so the case should be dismissed or transferred from Massachusetts to Washington state.
defenses.legal_basis: Enforcement of contractual forum selection clauses under federal law and 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a), arguing that the clause is mandatory and applicable to this dispute.

case_id: 2023-04-03_USCOURTS-mad-1_22-cv-11708_Groma_ LLC v. BuildRE_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Groma, LLC v. BuildRE, LLC et al.
ai_relevance: One defendant, Groma GPS-Turkey, designs AI-based vehicle automation software, but AI technology was not the subject of the legal claims; the dispute focused solely on trademark infringement and whether Massachusetts courts had personal jurisdiction over the out-of-state and foreign defendants.
ai_presence: The case summary notes that “one defendant, Groma GPS-Turkey, designs software using AI for vehicle automation,” indicating that this defendant’s business involves artificial intelligence technology, although the court’s decision turned on personal jurisdiction rather than the AI itself.

parties.plaintiff_description: Massachusetts-based business entity
parties.defendant_description: Texas and Turkey-based business entities

claims.claim: Trademark infringement against BuildRE, LLC and related entities for use of the Groma mark or similar branding.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trademark law (likely Lanham Act) as asserted by plaintiff.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without reaching merits because the court found it lacked personal jurisdiction over the Texas and Turkey-based defendants.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to stop defendants from using the allegedly infringing mark during the litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable injunctive relief ancillary to trademark infringement claims under federal and/or state law.
claims.outcome: Denied as moot because the court concluded it had no personal jurisdiction over defendants and dismissed the action.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in Massachusetts due to insufficient contacts with the forum state.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction and Massachusetts long-arm statute requirements.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; the court held it lacked personal jurisdiction and granted the motion to dismiss.

case_id: 2017-08-29_USCOURTS-cand-3_17-cv-03049_Purepredictive_ Inc. v. H20.AI_ Inc..pdf
case_name: PurePredictive, Inc. v. H2O.AI, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over patent on automated predictive analytics factory using machine learning.
ai_presence: The patent-in-suit, U.S. Patent No. 8,880,446, covers an “automated predictive analytics factory,” which automates the creation of predictive models using artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques. The court describes the claims as directed to mathematical algorithms and predictive analytics implemented on a generic computer, involving automated model generation and selection processes typical of machine learning systems.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation offering predictive analytics technology
parties.defendant_description: Corporation providing machine learning software

claims.claim: Patent infringement of U.S. Patent No. 8,880,446 related to an automated predictive analytics factory.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) based on alleged unauthorized use of the ’446 Patent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court held all asserted claims of the ’446 Patent are directed to patent-ineligible subject matter under 35 U.S.C. § 101 and thus cannot be infringed.

defenses.defense: The asserted patent claims are directed to abstract ideas involving mathematical algorithms and predictive analytics, implemented on generic computer components, and are therefore not patent-eligible.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Alice/Mayo two-step framework for patent eligibility (abstract idea without an inventive concept).

defenses.defense: The patent merely automates known statistical and mathematical techniques on a generic computer without improving computer functionality or providing a technological invention.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Supreme Court and Federal Circuit precedent on abstract ideas and generic computer implementation.

case_id: 2024-10-23_USCOURTS-mdd-1_23-cv-01822_Battle v. Microsoft Corporation.pdf
case_name: Battle v. Microsoft Corporation
ai_relevance: Dispute arises from Bing search and AI-driven Copilot chatbot misidentifying plaintiff as a terrorist.
ai_presence: The plaintiff alleged that Microsoft's Bing search engine and its AI-driven chatbot, Microsoft Copilot, conflated his identity with that of a convicted terrorist, leading to defamation and harm. The court’s summary notes that the claims are based on how Bing and the AI-driven Copilot presented information about the plaintiff.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer and Microsoft services user
parties.defendant_description: Multinational technology corporation, online services provider

claims.claim: Defamation and reputational harm from Bing search results and Microsoft Copilot associating plaintiff with a convicted terrorist.
claims.legal_basis: State-law defamation and related tort claims arising from online publication of false statements.
claims.outcome: Court did not reach merits; held claims subject to binding arbitration under Microsoft Services Agreement and stayed case pending arbitration.

claims.claim: General harm and damages caused by Microsoft’s services misidentifying plaintiff, including emotional distress and other injuries.
claims.legal_basis: State-law tort theories tied to use of Microsoft online services governed by the Microsoft Services Agreement.
claims.outcome: Substantive outcome reserved for arbitration; federal court compelled arbitration and stayed proceedings.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s claims must be resolved through arbitration under the Microsoft Services Agreement’s arbitration clause.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and contract law enforcing the arbitration provision in the Microsoft Services Agreement; motion to compel arbitration and stay litigation.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s claims fall within the scope of the Microsoft Services Agreement, which governs disputes arising from use of Microsoft services such as Bing and Copilot.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation of the Microsoft Services Agreement’s scope and dispute-resolution provisions.

case_id: 2025-03-25_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Dispute over Anthropic’s Claude AI models allegedly trained on copyrighted song lyrics without licenses, and AI outputs reproducing or distributing plaintiffs’ lyrics.
ai_presence: The case centers on Anthropic’s artificial intelligence model, Claude. Plaintiffs allege that Anthropic used copyrighted song lyrics owned or administered by music publishers to train its AI models without authorization or licenses. They contend that Claude can output substantial portions of their lyrics in response to user prompts, and that Anthropic’s ingestion, copying, and use of those lyrics in training datasets, model weights, and outputs infringes their copyrights. The requested preliminary injunction sought to stop Anthropic from using plaintiffs’ lyrics in training, retraining, or operating Claude and related AI systems, and from distributing or displaying plaintiffs’ lyrics through AI-generated outputs. The court’s order denying a preliminary injunction repeatedly discusses the operation of Anthropic’s AI models, the training process, and how Claude responds to prompts with lyrical content.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Music publishers and rights holders
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence research and deployment company

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s use of plaintiffs’ song lyrics to train its Claude AI models without authorization or license.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, including 17 U.S.C. §§ 106 and 501 (exclusive rights to reproduce, distribute, and prepare derivative works).
claims.outcome: On the preliminary injunction motion, the court did not decide ultimate liability but found plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of irreparable harm and therefore denied preliminary injunctive relief while the infringement claims proceed on the merits.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s reproduction and display of plaintiffs’ lyrics in Claude’s outputs in response to user prompts.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, including 17 U.S.C. §§ 106(1) and 106(3)–(5) (rights to reproduce, distribute, and publicly display copyrighted works).
claims.outcome: The court did not resolve the merits at this stage; it held that plaintiffs failed to demonstrate irreparable harm necessary for a preliminary injunction and therefore denied the requested immediate relief.

claims.claim: Contributory and/or vicarious copyright infringement arising from Anthropic enabling users of Claude to obtain infringing lyric outputs and allegedly benefiting from such use.
claims.legal_basis: Judge-made doctrines of secondary copyright liability under the Copyright Act (contributory and vicarious infringement).
claims.outcome: The court did not reach a final determination on secondary liability; it denied preliminary injunctive relief because plaintiffs did not establish a likelihood of irreparable harm pending final adjudication.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to bar Anthropic from using plaintiffs’ lyrics in training, retraining, or operating Claude and from reproducing, distributing, or displaying plaintiffs’ lyrics via Claude.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable remedy standards for preliminary injunctions under federal law (likelihood of success on the merits, irreparable harm, balance of equities, and public interest).
claims.outcome: Denied. The court held plaintiffs failed to show a likelihood of irreparable harm, so the extraordinary remedy of a preliminary injunction was not warranted at this time.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to show irreparable harm from Anthropic’s continued use of lyrics in training or operation of Claude pending final judgment.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard requiring proof of likely irreparable harm as articulated in cases such as Winter v. Natural Resources Defense Council and Ninth Circuit precedent.

defenses.defense: Any alleged harms are compensable by money damages and can be addressed through licensing or monetary relief rather than immediate injunctive relief.
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable principles limiting preliminary injunctions where legal remedies (damages) are adequate; federal injunction jurisprudence.

defenses.defense: Uncertainty regarding the extent to which Claude’s training on lyrics and its outputs actually displace or harm plaintiffs’ existing licensing markets at this stage of the litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard requiring a clear showing of likely, non-speculative irreparable harm; Ninth Circuit case law on speculative injuries not justifying injunctions.

case_id: 2014-11-17_USCOURTS-mied-2_13-cv-14026_Odish v. Morgenthaler Ventures et al.pdf
case_name: Odish v. Morgenthaler Ventures et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on alleged diminution of value and interests in Cognitive Code, Inc.’s artificial intelligence platform, SILVIA, which plaintiffs claim was harmed by defendants’ conduct.

The involvement of artificial intelligence is central to the plaintiff's claims, as the alleged wrongdoing by defendants pertains directly to the value and interests in the AI platform, SILVIA. SILVIA is characterized as an AI technology platform at the heart of the dispute.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual investor and consulting business entity
parties.defendant_description: Technology company and venture capital firm defendants

claims.claim: Defendants committed acts that diminished the value of Cognitive Code, Inc., particularly harming the value of its AI platform, SILVIA, thereby injuring plaintiffs’ ownership and economic interests.
claims.legal_basis: State-law business tort and contract-related claims (e.g., interference with business relations, breach of duties, and related corporate/ownership claims) asserted under Michigan law or applicable state law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without reaching merits because the court held it lacked personal jurisdiction over all defendants.

defenses.defense: The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan lacks personal jurisdiction over the defendants because they do not have sufficient contacts with Michigan.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2); minimum contacts and purposeful availment standards under U.S. Supreme Court and Sixth Circuit precedent.

case_id: 2016-02-29_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on alleged misappropriation of Loop’s AI technology and related trade secrets, including confidential information about its artificial intelligence systems and development.
ai_presence: The summary describes Loop AI Labs Inc. as “a startup developing AI technology” and explains that “Loop's technology [is] a core aspect of the trade secrets discussed.” The alleged trade secrets at issue are tied to this AI technology, and the discovery requests (subpoenas) seek documents and records related to the suspected misuse of Loop’s AI-related confidential information.

parties.plaintiff_description: Startup technology corporation developing AI systems
parties.defendant_description: Former CEO and related business entities

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to Loop’s AI technology and confidential business information.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret misappropriation under applicable state and/or federal trade secret law.
claims.outcome: Underlying claim not resolved in this order; court addressed only discovery, granting subpoenas in part and denying in part to obtain evidence relevant to this claim.

claims.claim: Other related business torts and statutory violations arising from alleged misuse of Loop’s confidential information and competitive activities by Gatti and associated entities.
claims.legal_basis: Unspecified in summary; likely includes breach of duty, unfair competition, and related statutory or common-law claims.
claims.outcome: Substantive outcome not decided in this order; court allowed limited third‑party discovery where requests were relevant and proportionate, and denied portions deemed overbroad or insufficiently justified.

defenses.defense: Objection that the third‑party subpoenas invade privacy rights, including personal financial and communications privacy of Gatti and related entities.
defenses.legal_basis: Privacy protections under federal and state law; proportionality and protection from undue burden under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26 and Rule 45.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court partially accepted this defense by narrowing time frames and scope of certain subpoenas to reduce privacy intrusion, but rejected it as to properly tailored, relevant requests.

defenses.defense: Objection that many subpoenaed documents are irrelevant to the trade secret and related claims and thus outside permissible discovery.
defenses.legal_basis: Relevance and proportionality limits on discovery under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1).
defenses.defense_outcome: Court sustained the objection in part, denying or limiting requests it found overly broad or not adequately tied to the issues, but overruled it for categories shown to be relevant to alleged misappropriation and related claims.

case_id: 2020-05-15_USCOURTS-azd-2_19-cv-04685_Modulus Financial Engineering Incorporated v. Modulus Data USA Incorporated et al.pdf
case_name: Modulus Financial Engineering Incorporated v. Modulus Data USA Incorporated et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation providing financial and software-related services
parties.defendant_name: Modulus Data USA & Modulus Data, Inc.
parties.defendant_description: Corporate defendants accused of trademark infringement

claims.claim: Federal trademark infringement based on defendants’ use of Modulus-related marks
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1114 and related provisions
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach merits

claims.claim: Unfair competition arising from alleged confusingly similar use of Modulus marks
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a), 15 U.S.C. § 1125(a), and/or analogous state law
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach merits

claims.claim: Cancellation of defendants’ trademark registrations incorporating Modulus-related terms
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1119 and related provisions
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach merits

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in Arizona federal court
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause and federal personal jurisdiction standards (minimum contacts, purposeful direction)

defenses.defense: Insufficient contacts or activities expressly aimed at Arizona to support specific jurisdiction
defenses.legal_basis: Ninth Circuit specific jurisdiction test (purposeful direction, arising out of forum-related activities, reasonableness)

case_id: 2020-06-25_USCOURTS-mad-1_19-cv-12551_Singular Computing LLC v. Google LLC.pdf
case_name: Singular Computing LLC v. Google LLC
ai_relevance: Patents cover specialized low-precision, high-dynamic-range arithmetic useful for AI workloads.
ai_presence: The summary explains that Singular’s patented methods of processing using Compact Arithmetic Processing Elements are designed to perform low precision and high dynamic range (LPHDR) arithmetic operations, which improve how computers handle tasks like artificial intelligence. It notes: “Imagine Singular Computing created a new way for computers to do math, allowing them to do it faster and with fewer parts. They got patents for these methods, believing this would improve how computers handle tasks like artificial intelligence.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology company holding processing patents
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation and service provider

claims.claim: Patent infringement of Singular’s patents covering methods of processing using Compact Arithmetic Processing Elements that perform low precision and high dynamic range (LPHDR) arithmetic operations.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) and related patent law doctrines; validity challenged under 35 U.S.C. § 101 (patentable subject matter).
claims.outcome: At motion-to-dismiss stage, claim allowed to proceed; court denied Google’s motion to dismiss based on § 101 ineligibility.

defenses.defense: Asserted patents are directed to abstract ideas and therefore claim unpatentable subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; abstract idea doctrine under Alice/Mayo framework; motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.

case_id: 2021-06-08_USCOURTS-cand-3_20-cv-09148_People.ai_ Inc. v. SetSail Technologies_ Inc..pdf
case_name: People.ai, Inc. v. SetSail Technologies, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on software patents for data analytics and CRM systems that involve machine learning-based functionality allegedly used in SetSail’s products.
ai_presence: The summary describes the asserted patents as “related to data analytics and CRM systems that involve machine learning.” The alleged infringement concerns SetSail’s “software products” that purportedly use these machine-learning-related patented techniques, but the court found People.ai failed to plead sufficient facts showing how SetSail’s software actually practices the claimed machine learning and data analytics elements.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation offering data analytics and CRM software
parties.defendant_description: Corporation providing sales and analytics software

claims.claim: Patent infringement of People.ai’s patents covering data analytics and CRM systems involving machine learning by SetSail’s software products.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 and related patent statutes.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss; court held complaint lacked sufficient factual allegations explaining how SetSail’s software met specific patent claim elements (“how and why” of infringement).

defenses.defense: The complaint fails to state a claim because it does not plausibly allege that SetSail’s software practices each element of the asserted patent claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) (failure to state a claim) and pleading standards under Twombly and Iqbal for patent infringement complaints.

case_id: 2021-09-01_USCOURTS-casd-3_20-cv-00862_Lin et al v. Suavei_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Lin et al. v. Suavei, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on alleged misrepresentations about a cybersecurity product using machine learning algorithms and containerized microservices architecture.
ai_presence: The summary describes “alleged misrepresentations of a technology product involving machine learning algorithms for cybersecurity” and states that “Plaintiffs claimed that the product did not possess the capabilities as represented, specifically regarding its containerized microservices architecture.” These AI/ML-related product capability representations are at the core of the investors’ claims.

parties.plaintiff_description: Group of investors in Suavei, Inc.
parties.defendant_description: Cybersecurity company and its board members

claims.claim: Breach of fiduciary duty by Suavei board members related to misrepresentations about the company’s cybersecurity product and its capabilities.
claims.legal_basis: State corporate law fiduciary duty principles (duty of care and loyalty) owed by directors/officers to stockholders.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; plaintiffs granted leave to amend to adequately allege breach of fiduciary duty.

claims.claim: Breach of duty of loyalty by Suavei board members in connection with alleged misleading statements about the machine-learning-based cybersecurity product and its architecture, harming stockholders.
claims.legal_basis: State corporate law duty of loyalty owed by directors/officers to stockholders, including prohibition on self-dealing and bad-faith conduct.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; plaintiffs allowed to amend to better plead duty of loyalty.

claims.claim: Direct claims by stockholder-plaintiffs for harm allegedly suffered personally from misrepresentations about the product’s capabilities (as opposed to purely derivative corporate harm).
claims.legal_basis: Corporate law distinction between direct and derivative stockholder claims; direct claims permitted where misrepresentations affect stockholders individually.
claims.outcome: Court allowed these allegations to remain; motion to strike paragraphs describing direct stockholder harm was denied.

claims.claim: Assertion of personal jurisdiction over Defendant Wong for claims arising from alleged misrepresentations and fiduciary breaches related to Suavei’s product and investment activities.
claims.legal_basis: Personal jurisdiction standards under due process and applicable long-arm statute (minimum contacts with the forum).
claims.outcome: Dismissed as to Defendant Wong; court held it lacked personal jurisdiction over her.

claims.claim: Assertion of personal jurisdiction over Defendant Infante for the same underlying misconduct related to Suavei’s product and investor communications.
claims.legal_basis: Personal jurisdiction standards under due process and applicable long-arm statute (sufficient contacts with the forum).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied; court found it has personal jurisdiction over Defendant Infante.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over Defendant Wong.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process clause and state long-arm statute requiring sufficient minimum contacts with the forum state.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over Defendant Infante.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process clause and state long-arm statute; argued insufficient contacts with the forum.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for breach of fiduciary duty and duty of loyalty because the complaint did not adequately plead the required elements.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim under applicable corporate fiduciary duty law.

defenses.defense: Alleged stockholder claims are derivative, not direct, and therefore certain paragraphs should be stricken as improper direct claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Corporate law distinction between direct and derivative claims; motion to strike under procedural rules (e.g., Rule 12(f)).

case_id: 2025-03-31_USCOURTS-flsd-0_24-cv-60715_Anderson v. MSC Cruises_ S.A..pdf
case_name: Anderson v. MSC Cruises S.A.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual cruise ship worker seaman
parties.defendant_description: Cruise line company and vessel operator

claims.claim: Negligence and related personal injury claims arising from injuries suffered aboard MSC’s vessel during his work assignment
claims.legal_basis: Maritime negligence and general maritime law; duties of vessel owner/operator to provide a reasonably safe place to work
claims.outcome: Compelled to arbitration; court granted MSC’s motion to compel arbitration and stayed/removed the claims from judicial forum

claims.claim: Claims premised on rights and obligations arising from his employment relationship with Espit Ventures, including safe working conditions and medical care while serving on MSC’s vessel
claims.legal_basis: Employment-related rights under his contract with Espit Ventures and applicable maritime/employment law
claims.outcome: Compelled to arbitration pursuant to the arbitration clause in the Espit employment contract, enforced in favor of MSC under equitable estoppel

defenses.defense: Claims must be resolved by arbitration under the arbitration clause in plaintiff’s employment contract with Espit Ventures
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and contractual arbitration clause designating arbitration in Panama under Maltese law

defenses.defense: As a non-signatory, MSC can enforce the arbitration agreement because plaintiff’s claims are intertwined with and dependent on his employment contract with Espit Ventures
defenses.legal_basis: Doctrine of equitable estoppel allowing non-signatory to compel arbitration where claims rely on or are intimately founded in the underlying contract

defenses.defense: Plaintiff is bound by his agreement to arbitrate and cannot avoid arbitration by suing a non-signatory vessel operator instead of his direct employer
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law principles of enforcing agreed dispute-resolution mechanisms and federal policy favoring arbitration

case_id: 2025-03-26_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Case concerns Anthropic’s AI model Claude allegedly trained on copyrighted song lyrics and outputting lyrics without authorization.
ai_presence: The summary describes that several music publishing companies sued Anthropic PBC, claiming that its AI, Claude, infringed their copyrights by using their song lyrics to train its language models without permission. The dispute centers on Anthropic’s AI model being trained on potentially copyrighted material and allegedly distributing songs in a way that could constitute contributory or vicarious infringement. The court’s analysis focuses on whether Anthropic’s AI, Claude, used and distributed songs in a manner that infringed copyright and whether it removed copyright management information in violation of the DMCA.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Music publishing companies and rights holders
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence technology company

claims.claim: Direct and/or primary copyright infringement based on use of song lyrics in training and outputs of the Claude AI model.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – unauthorized reproduction, distribution, and display of copyrighted song lyrics.
claims.outcome: Not addressed in the provided summary; only secondary infringement and DMCA CMI claims were dismissed with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Contributory copyright infringement for facilitating third parties’ infringing uses of plaintiffs’ song lyrics via the Claude AI model.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – secondary liability for materially contributing to or inducing direct infringement by users.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on Anthropic’s motion to dismiss for lack of specific allegations of direct third‑party infringement and insufficiently pled knowledge; dismissal with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Vicarious copyright infringement for profiting from and having the right and ability to control third‑party infringement via the Claude AI model.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – vicarious liability for financial benefit from and control over infringing activity by users.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on Anthropic’s motion to dismiss for failure to allege specific direct infringement and sufficient control/benefit details; dismissal with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Removal or alteration of copyright management information related to song lyrics used by the Claude AI model.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA), 17 U.S.C. § 1202 – prohibition on removal or alteration of copyright management information and distribution of works with CMI removed.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on Anthropic’s motion to dismiss for insufficient allegations that Anthropic knew or had reasonable grounds to know that CMI was removed or altered in connection with infringement; dismissal with leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to plead specific acts of direct infringement by any third party, a necessary predicate for contributory and vicarious infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Elements of secondary copyright liability under the Copyright Act require adequately pled direct infringement.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs did not sufficiently allege Anthropic’s knowledge of specific infringing acts or that its conduct induced, caused, or materially contributed to such infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Contributory infringement doctrine requiring knowledge and material contribution or inducement.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs did not adequately allege that Anthropic had the right and ability to supervise specific infringing conduct and a direct financial benefit from that infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Vicarious infringement doctrine under copyright law requiring control and financial benefit.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to allege facts showing Anthropic removed or altered copyright management information with the requisite knowledge that such removal would facilitate or conceal infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: DMCA § 1202 requires scienter that CMI removal or alteration will induce, enable, facilitate, or conceal infringement.

case_id: 2023-08-18_USCOURTS-dcd-1_22-cv-01564_THALER v. PERLMUTTER et al.pdf
case_name: Thaler v. Perlmutter et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over copyrightability of artwork autonomously generated by plaintiff’s AI system, the “Creativity Machine,” and whether such AI-only works can be protected under U.S. copyright law.
ai_presence: The case centers on a piece of visual art that was “autonomously generated by [Stephen Thaler’s] AI system, the ‘Creativity Machine.’” Thaler sought copyright registration listing the AI system as the author and himself as the owner, asserting that the work was created entirely by artificial intelligence without human involvement. The U.S. Copyright Office denied registration on the ground that the work lacked human authorship. The court’s opinion discusses “artificial intelligence,” “AI system,” and “autonomously generated” artwork, and holds that “works created without human involvement, like those generated solely by AI, are not eligible for copyright,” reaffirming that “copyright protection under U.S. law requires human authorship.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual AI developer and copyright applicant
parties.defendant_description: U.S. Copyright Office and related officials

claims.claim: Challenge to denial of copyright registration for AI-generated artwork, seeking judicial review and an order requiring registration of the work.
claims.legal_basis: Administrative Procedure Act and U.S. Copyright Act (alleged unlawful agency action in refusing registration based on lack of human authorship).
claims.outcome: Rejected. The court upheld the Copyright Office’s denial, holding that human authorship is required and the AI-generated work is not eligible for copyright.

claims.claim: Assertion that a work generated entirely by an AI system can qualify as a “work of authorship” under U.S. copyright law, with the AI’s owner as the copyright claimant.
claims.legal_basis: Interpretation of the Copyright Act’s terms “author” and “works of authorship,” and general principles of copyright ownership.
claims.outcome: Rejected. The court held that “author” under U.S. copyright law requires a human being, so a purely AI-generated work cannot be protected, and its owner cannot claim copyright.

defenses.defense: Human authorship is a prerequisite for copyright protection; purely AI-generated works lack a human author and therefore cannot be registered.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Copyright Act as interpreted by longstanding precedent requiring human authorship for copyrightable works.

defenses.defense: The Copyright Office acted within its statutory authority and did not act arbitrarily or capriciously in denying registration for lack of human authorship.
defenses.legal_basis: Administrative Procedure Act standards for judicial review of agency action and the Office’s regulations and practices concerning authorship.

case_id: 2016-06-30_USCOURTS-nmd-1_14-cv-00965_Clark v. Dashner et al.pdf
case_name: Clark v. Dashner et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Author and his book publisher
parties.defendant_description: Author and associated publishing-related defendants

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on allegations that James Dashner’s novel "The Maze Runner" copied protectable elements of Clark’s earlier novel "The Maze."
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law under the Copyright Act (17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court found no substantial similarity in protectable expression and that overlapping elements were unprotectable ideas and genre concepts.

claims.claim: Unfair trade practices arising from alleged copying and exploitation of "The Maze" through publication and distribution of "The Maze Runner."
claims.legal_basis: State unfair trade practices statute (unfair or deceptive trade practices).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as preempted by federal copyright law and not independently viable.

claims.claim: Unfair competition based on alleged misappropriation of the concept and market for "The Maze" by publishing and profiting from "The Maze Runner."
claims.legal_basis: State common-law unfair competition and related doctrines.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as preempted by federal copyright law and lacking a distinct, non-preempted basis.

defenses.defense: No substantial similarity between protectable elements of the two works; any similarities concern general ideas, concepts, and scènes à faire common to the genre.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright law’s idea–expression dichotomy and substantial similarity standard under the Copyright Act.

defenses.defense: Allegedly copied elements are unprotectable ideas, concepts, and stock elements, such as a dangerous maze, moving walls, and robotic creatures.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 102(b) (exclusion of ideas, concepts, and systems from copyright protection).

defenses.defense: State-law unfair trade practices and unfair competition claims are preempted by federal copyright law because they do not contain extra elements beyond rights equivalent to copyright.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act preemption, 17 U.S.C. § 301.

case_id: 2011-04-04_USCOURTS-cand-5_05-cv-03534_Goldberg v. Cameron et al.pdf
case_name: Goldberg v. Cameron et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual screenwriter and composer
parties.defendant_name: Gale Anne Hurd; Pacific Western Productions
parties.defendant_description: Film producer and production company

claims.claim: Contributory copyright infringement based on alleged use of plaintiff’s script "Long Live Music" and soundtrack "Energy" in the Terminator film franchise.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, contributory infringement (17 U.S.C. § 501 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted for defendants; court found no substantial similarity and no evidence of access or knowledge, so the contributory infringement claim failed.

defenses.defense: No substantial similarity between plaintiff’s works and the Terminator films.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright infringement requires substantial similarity of protectable expression.

defenses.defense: Lack of access or knowledge of plaintiff’s works by Gale Anne Hurd before creation of the films.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright infringement and contributory infringement require proof of access or knowledge.

defenses.defense: Failure of contributory infringement claim because no underlying direct infringement can be established.
defenses.legal_basis: Contributory liability requires an underlying act of direct infringement.

case_id: 2024-08-14_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-06049_Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies Inc..pdf
case_name: Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies Inc.

These AI-powered cameras and related driver safety systems are the technological subject of the alleged misappropriation and patent infringement.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation providing AI-powered dashboard cameras
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation offering driver safety telematics products

claims.claim: Misappropriation or theft of proprietary driver safety and camera technology.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret and proprietary technology misappropriation under applicable state and federal law (exact statutes not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this opinion; case transferred to the Northern District of California for further proceedings.

claims.claim: Patent infringement relating to driver safety and AI-powered dashboard camera technology.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under federal patent law (35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq., implied from context).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this opinion; case transferred to the Northern District of California for further proceedings.

claims.claim: Procedural request to keep the action in the original Delaware venue.
claims.legal_basis: Opposition to transfer under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a), arguing Delaware is a proper and convenient forum.
claims.outcome: Denied; the court granted the motion to transfer the case to the Northern District of California.

defenses.defense: Motion to transfer venue from Delaware to the Northern District of California for convenience and justice.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) – transfer of venue in the interest of convenience of parties and witnesses and the interest of justice.

case_id: 2025-01-23_USCOURTS-ksd-6_24-cv-01055_Pathways Management Services_ LLC et al v. Northstar Hospital et al.pdf
case_name: Pathways Management Services, LLC et al. v. NorthStar Hospital et al.
ai_relevance: Protective order restricts use of confidential discovery materials with AI, prohibiting submission of such information to open generative AI tools during litigation.
ai_presence: The case summary states that the protective order "notably addresses the use of artificial intelligence by limiting how AI tools can handle confidential information, specifically prohibiting submission of such information to open generative AI tools." The order "mandates strict control over how this information can be used, including specific provisions about disclosure to AI tools."

parties.plaintiff_description: Business entity operating healthcare-related services
parties.defendant_description: Hospital and related business defendants

claims.claim: Misappropriation of confidential business information and trade secrets to establish a competing facility.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret misappropriation and unfair competition under applicable trade secret and unfair competition laws.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; court issued a protective order governing use and disclosure of confidential information during discovery, but has not yet resolved liability on the misappropriation claim.

claims.claim: Unfair competition by using Pathways’ proprietary information to compete against it.
claims.legal_basis: Unfair competition doctrines tied to misuse of confidential and proprietary business information.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; no final ruling on unfair competition, but discovery is proceeding under a strict protective order limiting use and disclosure of confidential materials, including to AI tools.

defenses.defense: Any alleged information is not a protectable trade secret or confidential information.
defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret law requirements that information be secret and derive independent economic value from secrecy.

defenses.defense: Defendants did not misappropriate or improperly use plaintiffs’ information in establishing the competing facility.
defenses.legal_basis: General denial of misappropriation and lack of wrongful acquisition, disclosure, or use under trade secret and unfair competition law.

defenses.defense: Use of information, if any, was lawful and/or independently obtained.
defenses.legal_basis: Defenses of independent development, lawful acquisition, and absence of improper means under trade secret statutes and common law.

case_id: 2025-07-29_USCOURTS-tned-3_24-cv-00329_Axis Dynamics et al v. Knox County Tennessee et al.pdf

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual teacher and putative class representative
parties.defendant_description: Online education companies and related corporate defendants

claims.claim: Deceptive and unfair business practices related to the undisclosed capture and use of biometric data and other information from teachers.

claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice to arbitration; court compelled arbitration pursuant to the Independent Contractor Agreement.
