case_id: 2021-02-17_USCOURTS-cand-4_19-cv-04060_Lambda Labs_ Inc. v. Lambda_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Lambda Labs, Inc. v. Lambda, Inc.
ai_relevance: The dispute concerns trademarks and discovery about parties’ artificial intelligence and machine learning products and services, including how those AI/ML offerings are marketed and sold.
ai_presence: The summary states that the dispute is “in the context of a trademark disagreement, which centers on offerings related to artificial intelligence and machine learning products and services.” It further explains that the key legal issue is whether Lambda Labs provided sufficient detail in interrogatory responses “regarding its AI and ML products and services, their associated trademarks, and the completeness of their trade and customer information.” The court orders Lambda Labs “to amend its responses to provide more detailed and complete information as required by the interrogatories, specifically focusing on AI and ML offerings.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation offering AI/ML products and services
parties.defendant_description: Corporation operating as Lambda School

claims.claim: Trademark-related claims concerning confusion between Lambda Labs’ marks and Lambda School’s marks, including how AI and ML products and services are branded and marketed.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trademark infringement and related unfair competition laws (exact statutes not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this discovery order; underlying trademark claims remain pending.

claims.claim: Discovery-related request that Lambda Labs provide more detailed and complete interrogatory responses about its AI and ML products and services, associated trademarks, and trade and customer information.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing discovery, including Rules 26 and 33 (interrogatories and scope of discovery).
claims.outcome: Court grants Lambda, Inc.’s motion to compel in substance and orders Lambda Labs to amend and supplement its interrogatory responses with more detailed and complete information, particularly about AI and ML offerings.

defenses.defense: Lambda Labs’ existing interrogatory responses were sufficient and did not require further detail or supplementation.
defenses.legal_basis: Objections under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure to discovery as overly burdensome, unnecessary, or already adequately answered (specific rules not detailed in summary).

defenses.defense: Lambda, Inc. (Lambda School) sought a protective order to limit or block certain deposition questions, particularly those concerning reputational issues and confusion related to the trademarks.
defenses.legal_basis: Motion for protective order under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) to restrict discovery deemed harassing, irrelevant, or unduly burdensome.

case_id: 2020-07-30_USCOURTS-mad-1_19-cv-12235_Mantha v. Quotewizard.com_ LLC.pdf
case_name: Mantha v. QuoteWizard.com, LLC
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on use of an AI-driven automated texting service (Drips LLC) to send marketing texts, allegedly as an Automatic Telephone Dialing System under the TCPA.
ai_presence: The court’s summary indicates that new evidence showed QuoteWizard used “an AI-driven service by Drips LLC to send automated messages.” The amended complaint alleges that the text messages at issue were sent using this AI-driven automated texting platform, which is characterized as an Automatic Telephone Dialing System (ATDS) under the TCPA. The court relies on these new allegations about the AI-driven messaging system to conclude that the amended complaint now plausibly states a TCPA claim and should proceed to discovery.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer receiving marketing text messages
parties.defendant_description: Business entity offering insurance quote services

claims.claim: Violation of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act by sending unauthorized marketing text messages using an Automatic Telephone Dialing System without prior express consent.
claims.legal_basis: Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA), 47 U.S.C. § 227(b) (prohibiting calls or texts to cell phones using an automatic telephone dialing system without prior express consent).
claims.outcome: Initially dismissed for insufficient factual allegations regarding use of an ATDS; court later granted leave to amend and held the amended complaint plausibly states a TCPA claim based on new allegations about the AI-driven automated texting service, allowing the claim to proceed to discovery.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to adequately allege that the text messages were sent using an Automatic Telephone Dialing System as defined by the TCPA.
defenses.legal_basis: TCPA statutory definition of an ATDS under 47 U.S.C. § 227(a)(1) and related case law requiring specific factual allegations about the system’s capacity to store or produce numbers using a random or sequential number generator.

defenses.defense: Prior dismissal of the complaint for lack of sufficient factual support regarding the nature of the dialing system used.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and Rule 8, requiring plausible factual allegations rather than conclusory statements.

case_id: 2023-04-05_USCOURTS-ca13-23-01230_Aljindi v. US.pdf
case_name: Aljindi v. United States
ai_relevance: Plaintiff claimed copyright in his contributions to Artificial Intelligence, alleging the U.S. used his AI-related ideas without authorization.
ai_presence: The summary states that Dr. Ahmad Aljindi alleged "copyright infringement related to his contributions to the fields of Artificial Intelligence (AI), Information Security, and Legacy Information Systems (LIS)."

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual pro se plaintiff, researcher and author
parties.defendant_description: Federal government of the United States

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged unauthorized use of his contributions and ideas in Artificial Intelligence (AI).
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law protecting original works of authorship
claims.outcome: Dismissed by Court of Federal Claims for failure to state a claim; affirmed on appeal because ideas and principles in AI are not copyrightable expression.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged unauthorized use of his contributions and ideas in Information Security.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law protecting original works of authorship
claims.outcome: Dismissed by Court of Federal Claims for failure to state a claim; affirmed on appeal because ideas and principles in information security are not copyrightable expression.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged unauthorized use of his contributions and ideas in Legacy Information Systems (LIS).
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law protecting original works of authorship
claims.outcome: Dismissed by Court of Federal Claims for failure to state a claim; affirmed on appeal because ideas and principles in legacy information systems are not copyrightable expression.

claims.claim: General claims that the United States misappropriated or exploited his scientific and technical ideas without permission or compensation.
claims.legal_basis: Treated as copyright-based claims; subject to the idea–expression dichotomy under copyright law
claims.outcome: Dismissed because allegations concerned unprotectable ideas and concepts, not specific fixed expressions; dismissal affirmed on appeal.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s allegations concern ideas, concepts, and principles, which are not protected by copyright law.
defenses.legal_basis: Idea–expression dichotomy under federal copyright law; 17 U.S.C. § 102(b).

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted because it does not identify any specific protectable expression that was copied.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under applicable pleading standards (e.g., RCFC 12(b)(6)/Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6) analogue).

defenses.defense: To the extent plaintiff asserts broader grievances about use of his scientific work, such theories fall outside the Court of Federal Claims’ jurisdiction.
defenses.legal_basis: Limits on jurisdiction of the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act and related jurisdictional doctrines.

case_id: 2019-07-30_USCOURTS-mad-1_19-cv-10019_Wired Infomatics_ LLC v. OmniMD.pdf
case_name: Wired Informatics, LLC v. OmniMD Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Wired’s “Invenio” software, intended to serve as an artificial intelligence engine for OmniMD’s products; alleged misrepresentations and warranty breaches concern the AI capabilities and performance of this system.
ai_presence: The summary states that OmniMD’s counterclaims involve “Wired's "Invenio" software, which OmniMD intended to use as an artificial intelligence engine.” The case discusses alleged fraud and breach of implied warranties relating to this AI-powered software product and its promised capabilities as an AI engine.

parties.plaintiff_description: Software developer company providing Invenio AI engine
parties.defendant_description: Former client healthcare software company

claims.claim: Breach of contract by OmniMD in its dealings with Wired Informatics regarding the Invenio software and related services.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law – alleged failure to perform obligations under the software development and licensing agreement between Wired and OmniMD.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; the decision addresses only OmniMD’s counterclaims, and Wired’s affirmative contract claims remain pending.

claims.claim: Fraud by Wired in connection with the Invenio software’s capabilities and performance as an artificial intelligence engine (OmniMD’s counterclaim).
claims.legal_basis: Common-law fraud, requiring particularized pleading under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 9(b).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for insufficient pleading; the court held OmniMD failed to meet Rule 9(b)’s heightened specificity requirements but granted leave to amend.

claims.claim: Breach of implied warranties by Wired relating to the Invenio software, including its quality, fitness for OmniMD’s intended AI use, and merchantability (OmniMD’s counterclaim).
claims.legal_basis: Implied warranty of merchantability and implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose under applicable commercial and UCC-based principles, subject to contractual warranty disclaimers.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; the court found OmniMD did not adequately plead around or overcome the contract’s disclaimer of warranties but allowed OmniMD to file an amended counterclaim.

defenses.defense: OmniMD’s fraud counterclaim is inadequately pleaded and fails to satisfy the heightened particularity requirements for fraud.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 9(b) and governing fraud-pleading standards; motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.

defenses.defense: OmniMD’s implied warranty counterclaims are barred or limited by the contract’s express disclaimer of implied warranties regarding the Invenio software.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law and UCC principles enforcing valid warranty disclaimers; motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6) for failure to state a claim in light of the disclaimer.

case_id: 2015-01-29_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_13-cv-04417_Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC and Daimler AG
ai_relevance: Patent concerns an AI-style expert system that screens equipment operators for impairments and controls operation based on computerized impairment assessments.
ai_presence: The patent-in-suit, U.S. Patent No. 7,394,392, describes and claims methods and systems that use an “expert system” to screen equipment operators for impairments (such as intoxication, fatigue, or other conditions) and to control or prevent operation of the equipment based on the results of that screening. The summary explains that the invention involves “using expert systems to screen equipment operators for impairments and control equipment operation based on those screenings,” and characterizes these expert systems as a form of computerized AI used to assess operator impairment. The court’s analysis treats this as a computerized implementation of the abstract idea of testing operators for impairments, concluding that the claimed expert-system-based screening and control lacks an inventive concept sufficient to render it patent-eligible under 35 U.S.C. § 101.

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding business entity
parties.defendant_description: Automobile manufacturer and U.S. affiliate

claims.claim: Patent infringement of U.S. Patent No. 7,394,392 relating to expert-system-based screening of equipment operators for impairments and controlling equipment operation based on those screenings.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) asserting rights in a patent allegedly covering AI-style expert systems for operator impairment screening.
claims.outcome: Rejected. Court held all asserted claims of the ’392 patent invalid as directed to an abstract idea without an inventive concept and therefore ineligible for patent protection under 35 U.S.C. § 101; judgment entered for defendants.

defenses.defense: The asserted ’392 patent claims are directed to an abstract idea—testing equipment operators for impairments using generic computer implementation—and therefore are not patent-eligible subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (patent-eligibility; abstract idea doctrine under Alice/Mayo framework).

defenses.defense: Even if computerized, the claimed expert-system screening and control functions use only conventional computer components and do not add an inventive concept sufficient to transform the abstract idea into patent-eligible subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (lack of inventive concept beyond abstract idea).

case_id: 2024-06-05_USCOURTS-jpml-1_24-F-03109_IN RE_ Video Game Addiction Products Liability Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Video Game Addiction Products Liability Litigation
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege video games use artificial intelligence-driven mechanisms and algorithms, alongside feedback loops, reward systems, and pay-to-win features, to increase engagement and create addictive gameplay, particularly targeting minors and young adults.
ai_presence: The summary states that plaintiffs allege “Artificial intelligence (AI) mechanisms, alongside feedback loops, reward systems, and pay-to-win options, are alleged to be part of these addictive features.” AI is thus mentioned as one of the technological mechanisms embedded in the video games that purportedly contribute to addictive design and user addiction.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individuals alleging addiction from video games
parties.defendant_description: Video game developers and technology companies

claims.claim: Video game companies deliberately designed games with addictive features that trap minors and young adults in prolonged gameplay, causing or contributing to addiction and related harms.
claims.legal_basis: Products liability and negligence theories based on allegedly defective, unreasonably dangerous, and negligently designed products; possibly consumer protection and failure-to-warn claims (as implied by products liability framing).
claims.outcome: No ruling on the merits of the addiction or products liability claims; the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation denied centralization of these actions into an MDL, leaving each underlying case to proceed separately in its respective district.

claims.claim: Artificial intelligence mechanisms, feedback loops, reward systems, and pay-to-win options were intentionally incorporated into the games to enhance addictiveness and exploit users, especially minors and young adults.
claims.legal_basis: Products liability and negligence, including design defect and possibly unfair or deceptive practices under consumer protection statutes, premised on intentional use of AI and algorithmic features to promote addictive behavior.
claims.outcome: The Panel did not adjudicate this substantive claim; it only decided that these AI-related and design-defect allegations did not present sufficiently common factual questions across all actions to justify MDL centralization, so the motion to centralize was denied.

claims.claim: The various lawsuits concerning video game addiction share common factual questions such that they should be centralized into a single multidistrict litigation for coordinated pretrial proceedings.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1407, which allows centralization of civil actions involving one or more common questions of fact when it would serve the convenience of parties and witnesses and promote the just and efficient conduct of the litigation.
claims.outcome: The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation denied the motion to centralize, holding that the actions did not share sufficient common factual questions and that centralization would not promote convenience or the just and efficient conduct of the litigation due to differing games, defendants, and factual circumstances.

defenses.defense: The actions do not share sufficient common factual questions to warrant centralization into an MDL because they involve different video games, different sets of defendants, and varied factual circumstances.
defenses.legal_basis: Opposition to MDL centralization under 28 U.S.C. § 1407, arguing that the statutory requirement of “one or more common questions of fact” and the efficiency and convenience criteria are not satisfied.

defenses.defense: Centralization would not promote the convenience of parties or witnesses nor facilitate the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, given the diversity of products, companies, and alleged harms.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1407 factors concerning convenience and the just and efficient conduct of actions, used to argue against creation of an MDL.

case_id: 2025-09-16_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege Anthropic used copyrighted songs to train its AI tool, raising novel copyright-infringement and damages issues involving AI training data.
ai_presence: The case summary states that Concord Music Group, Inc. and others sued Anthropic PBC for copyright infringement, alleging that Anthropic used copyright-protected songs to train its AI tool. The court notes that this is a novel intersection of copyright law and AI technology and adopts a pragmatic approach to Rule 26 damages disclosure requirements in light of the AI training context.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Music publishers and related rights holders
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence technology company

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s use of plaintiffs’ copyrighted songs to train its AI tool without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act (17 U.S.C.), including exclusive rights to reproduce and prepare derivative works; asserted via federal copyright infringement claims.
claims.outcome: On the specific discovery dispute, the court declined to exclude or limit plaintiffs’ damages evidence and did not resolve ultimate liability; it ordered plaintiffs to provide more detailed damages computations by the close of fact discovery.

claims.claim: Claim for monetary damages for alleged unauthorized use of musical works in AI training, including potential actual or statutory damages.
claims.legal_basis: Damages provisions of the Copyright Act (17 U.S.C. §§ 504 et seq.) and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(a)(1)(A)(iii) governing disclosure of a computation of each category of damages.
claims.outcome: The court held that plaintiffs’ existing Rule 26 damages disclosures were not so deficient as to warrant immediate supplementation or exclusion; it required plaintiffs to supplement with as much detail as reasonably possible by the end of fact discovery.

defenses.defense: Challenge to sufficiency of plaintiffs’ Rule 26(a)(1)(A)(iii) damages computation disclosures, seeking immediate supplementation or exclusion of damages evidence.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(a)(1)(A)(iii) and Rule 37(c)(1) (sanctions and exclusion for failure to disclose).

case_id: 2022-08-26_USCOURTS-cand-5_19-cv-04286_In re Google Assistant Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Google Assistant Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Case concerns proprietary tools and services used to enhance Google’s AI products, including Google Assistant, and whether related confidential business information may be sealed.
ai_presence: Appen provides tools and services to enhance Google’s artificial intelligence products, which were considered sensitive and non-public business information.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of Google Assistant users
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating Google Assistant platform

claims.claim: Non-party Appen Butler Hill Inc. sought to keep under seal a Statement of Work and related submissions describing its services and pricing for work performed for Google in connection with Google Assistant.
claims.legal_basis: Protective sealing of confidential business and financial information; “good cause” standard for sealing materials only tangentially related to the merits of the case under Ninth Circuit precedent and local rules.
claims.outcome: The court granted Appen’s motion to seal, finding good cause because the documents contained proprietary, competitively sensitive, and non-public business information.

defenses.defense: The confidential Statement of Work and related documents contain proprietary, competitively sensitive information about Appen’s services and pricing that, if disclosed, would harm its competitive standing.
defenses.legal_basis: Good cause standard for sealing non-dispositive or tangentially related materials; protection of trade secrets and confidential commercial information under federal common law and local rules.

case_id: 2025-11-04_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-01451_In Re Mosaic LLM Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Mosaic LLM Litigation
ai_relevance: Central dispute over discovery into generative AI tools, AI training data, and licensing relevant to fair use analysis for AI models.
ai_presence: The case involves discovery disputes about electronic searches for documents related to AI technology. Defendants requested that plaintiffs run broad search terms linked to third-party AI tools and licensing agreements for AI training data. The court described these requests as overly broad and not specifically relevant to the case’s needs. The involvement of AI is central to determining issues of fair use and licensing in relation to generative AI models, including plaintiffs’ use and knowledge of AI tools and documents concerning licensing agreements for AI training data. The court’s ruling addresses how information about AI tools, generative AI models, and AI training data should be discovered and limited to what is relevant and proportionate to defendants’ fair use defense under U.S. copyright law.

parties.plaintiff_description: Group of plaintiffs challenging generative AI practices
parties.defendant_description: Entities defending generative AI model practices

claims.claim: Defendants seek broad discovery into plaintiffs’ use and knowledge of AI tools and related documents, including references to third-party AI tools such as ChatGPT and others.
claims.legal_basis: Federal civil discovery rules requiring production of nonprivileged, relevant, and proportional information (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(1)).
claims.outcome: Court denied defendants’ request for plaintiffs to run broad AI-related search terms, finding them overly broad and not sufficiently tied to the issues in the case.

claims.claim: Defendants seek discovery of documents and communications concerning licensing agreements for AI training data, including plaintiffs’ licensing practices and negotiations.
claims.legal_basis: Federal civil discovery rules on relevance and proportionality to defenses, including fair use and market harm (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(1)).
claims.outcome: Court denied the broad proposed search terms targeting licensing agreements for AI training data as not specifically relevant or proportionate, but allowed defendants to propose a limited number of narrower replacement terms.

claims.claim: Defendants seek information about where plaintiffs’ works are available online to support their fair use and market impact defenses.
claims.legal_basis: Relevance to fair use factors and market impact under U.S. copyright law, obtained through discovery under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26.
claims.outcome: Court ordered plaintiffs to supplement their discovery responses by making a reasonable effort to identify locations where their works are available online.

defenses.defense: Defendants assert a fair use defense, arguing that information about plaintiffs’ use of AI tools and licensing of AI training data is relevant to assessing fair use and market impact.
defenses.legal_basis: Fair use doctrine under U.S. copyright law (17 U.S.C. § 107) and related discovery standards of relevance and proportionality under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(1).

case_id: 2006-02-14_USCOURTS-waed-2_05-cv-00380_Next It Corporation v. Roy et al.pdf
case_name: Next IT Corporation v. Joshua Knowles (and others)
ai_relevance: Dispute over proprietary artificial intelligence application technology and related trade secrets.
ai_presence: "proprietary technology related to artificial intelligence applications"; "protection of trade secrets and proprietary information, specifically concerning the use and potential dissemination of confidential technology-related information"; "activities that compete with Next IT software applications or involve similar technology".

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation providing AI software applications
parties.defendant_description: Former employee and individual technologist

claims.claim: Misappropriation and threatened misappropriation of trade secrets and proprietary technology information Knowles accessed during employment.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret and proprietary information law; contractual and equitable protection of confidential business information.
claims.outcome: Resolved by stipulated permanent injunction barring disclosure or use of Next IT proprietary information indefinitely.

claims.claim: Breach or threatened breach of confidentiality and non-disclosure obligations regarding Next IT’s proprietary technology and software applications.
claims.legal_basis: Confidentiality and non-disclosure duties arising from employment relationship and agreements; equitable injunctive relief standards.
claims.outcome: Court approved stipulated order permanently enjoining Knowles from disclosing any proprietary information of Next IT.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and risk of competitive use of similar software and technology by Knowles after leaving Next IT.
claims.legal_basis: Unfair competition principles and enforceability of reasonable restrictive covenants to protect trade secrets and goodwill.
claims.outcome: Knowles enjoined for three years from engaging in activities that compete with Next IT software applications or involve similar technology.

claims.claim: Risk of interference with Next IT’s workforce through solicitation or recruitment of its current employees.
claims.legal_basis: Contract and common-law protection against improper employee raiding; enforceability of non-solicitation covenants.
claims.outcome: Knowles enjoined for one year from recruiting or soliciting current employees of Next IT.

claims.claim: Potential reputational harm through disparaging or defamatory statements between the parties.
claims.legal_basis: Defamation and business disparagement principles; contractual non-disparagement undertakings.
claims.outcome: Injunction incorporates a mutual non-defamation agreement binding both parties.

defenses.defense: Resolution by stipulation without adjudication of liability, implying no admission of wrongdoing by Knowles.
defenses.legal_basis: Parties’ contractual settlement rights and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure provisions allowing stipulated injunctions.

case_id: 2024-09-25_USCOURTS-ksd-5_15-cv-03098_Jones _ID 59073_ v. United States Copyright Office and Patents.pdf
case_name: Joseph Lee Jones v. United States Copyright Office and Patents
ai_relevance: Plaintiff sought copyright and patent protections for his artificial intelligence research and related submissions.
ai_presence: The summary states: "the plaintiff sought mandamus relief to obtain forms for copyright and patent submissions related to his research on artificial intelligence" and "The case involves AI as the plaintiff's submissions were focused on obtaining intellectual property rights for his AI research."

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual prisoner litigant and AI researcher
parties.defendant_name: United States Copyright Office and Patents
parties.defendant_description: Federal intellectual property offices and related officials

claims.claim: Request for writ of mandamus compelling provision of copyright and patent submission forms for his artificial intelligence research and related works.
claims.legal_basis: Mandamus relief under federal law; access to copyright and patent application processes.
claims.outcome: Dismissed when the underlying case was terminated for failure to pay the required district court filing fee under the prisoner three-strikes rule; no mandamus relief granted.

claims.claim: Motion(s) for relief from judgment to reopen the dismissed case so he could pursue copyright and patent-related relief for his AI research.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b), including alleged mistake, newly discovered evidence, or other exceptional circumstances justifying relief from final judgment.
claims.outcome: Denied; the court held plaintiff failed to show any exceptional circumstances or valid Rule 60(b) grounds, so the judgment stood and the case remained closed.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff is barred from proceeding without prepaying the filing fee because he is a prisoner subject to the three-strikes rule and did not pay the fee.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(g) (Prison Litigation Reform Act three-strikes provision) and district court filing-fee requirements.

defenses.defense: No exceptional circumstances or qualifying grounds exist to justify relief from the prior dismissal under Rule 60(b).
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b) standards for relief from final judgment, including the requirement of extraordinary or exceptional circumstances.

case_id: 2021-02-23_USCOURTS-ksd-5_15-cv-03098_Jones _ID 59073_ v. United States Copyright Office and Patents.pdf
case_name: Jones v. United States Copyright Office and Patents
ai_relevance: Plaintiff’s underlying works concern published research on artificial intelligence and a “Fractal,” which he sought to protect via copyright, patent, or trademark forms.
ai_presence: The summary states that Joseph Lee Jones sought mandamus relief "related to difficulties in obtaining copyright and patent forms for his published research on artificial intelligence (AI) and his ability to file forms for patent or trademark a 'Fractal.'" AI is mentioned as the subject matter of his published research that he wanted to protect through intellectual property filings.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual prisoner and pro se litigant
parties.defendant_description: Federal government intellectual property agencies and officials

claims.claim: Request for mandamus relief compelling provision of copyright and patent (and possibly trademark) forms so he could protect his published research on artificial intelligence and a “Fractal.”
claims.legal_basis: Petition for writ of mandamus; access to copyright and patent processes; implied constitutional right of access to courts and to seek intellectual property protection.
claims.outcome: Dismissed at screening under the Prison Litigation Reform Act “3-strike” rule; court refused to allow case to proceed without full filing fee because plaintiff was not under imminent danger of serious physical injury.

claims.claim: Request to be relieved from the requirement to pay the full district court filing fee despite being subject to the “3-strike” rule, based on his IP-related claims about AI research and a Fractal.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(g) (PLRA 3-strike rule) and equitable arguments that his circumstances warranted exception to the fee requirement.
claims.outcome: Denied; court held § 1915(g) barred in forma pauperis status absent imminent danger, which was not shown, so full filing fee requirement remained.

claims.claim: Motion for relief from judgment under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b), arguing that the prior dismissal and fee ruling were erroneous and should be set aside so he could pursue his mandamus/IP claims.
claims.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 60(b) (relief from judgment for mistake, newly discovered evidence, fraud, or other exceptional circumstances).
claims.outcome: Denied; court found no grounds under Rule 60(b), no exceptional circumstances, no showing of mistake or new evidence, and held the motion was untimely.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff is barred from proceeding in forma pauperis by the Prison Litigation Reform Act “3-strike” rule because he has had three or more prior actions dismissed as frivolous, malicious, or for failure to state a claim, and he did not allege imminent danger of serious physical injury.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(g) (PLRA 3-strike provision).

defenses.defense: Relief from judgment is unwarranted because plaintiff failed to show mistake, newly discovered evidence, fraud, or any other exceptional circumstance justifying reopening the case, and his Rule 60(b) motion was filed outside a reasonable time.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b) and related timeliness and exceptional-circumstances standards.

case_id: 2024-09-12_USCOURTS-mied-2_24-cv-11786_Robinson v. Global Semiconductor Alliance.pdf
case_name: Robinson v. Global Semiconductor Alliance
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges his patented Fiber-Optic Connected Logic is being used without authorization to run various AI programs, forming the core of the alleged infringement dispute.
ai_presence: The plaintiff, Kay C. Robinson, Jr., alleged that unnamed entities are utilizing Robinson's patented Fiber-Optic Connected Logic (FOCL) to run various AI programs. The case highlights the involvement of AI as Robinson's patent is allegedly used to support AI programs without proper authorization.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual patent holder and inventor
parties.defendant_description: Industry association in semiconductor sector

claims.claim: Unnamed entities, allegedly connected to or associated with Global Semiconductor Alliance, are using Robinson’s patented Fiber-Optic Connected Logic (FOCL) technology without authorization to run various AI programs, constituting patent infringement or unauthorized use of patented technology.
claims.legal_basis: Implied patent infringement / unauthorized use of patented technology under U.S. patent law (though not adequately pleaded).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for failure to state a claim; court found the complaint lacked sufficient factual detail tying any infringing conduct to the named defendant, Global Semiconductor Alliance.

defenses.defense: The complaint fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted because it does not allege specific facts showing that Global Semiconductor Alliance engaged in any infringing conduct or other actionable wrongdoing.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) standard and plausibility requirement under Twombly/Iqbal for stating a claim.

case_id: 2016-03-30_USCOURTS-paed-2_15-cv-05387_DUCKWEED_ USA_ INC. et al v. BEHRENS et al.pdf
case_name: Duckweed USA, Inc. et al. v. Behrens et al.
ai_relevance: Licensed clean‑energy technology allegedly required an essential artificial intelligence component to operate, and that AI-based system was central to the patented invention and the infringement dispute.
ai_presence: The summary states: "Duckweed claimed its licensed technology involved an essential 'artificial intelligence' component necessary for operating certain clean-energy systems." This AI component was described as necessary for operating the patented clean‑energy systems at issue in the case.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation licensing clean-energy patent technology
parties.defendant_description: Individual patent owner and associated defendants

claims.claim: Patent infringement
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law; infringement of an exclusively licensed patent by unauthorized use, including by the original patent owner
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to standing; court held Duckweed had standing to sue for patent infringement based on its exclusive license, even though the alleged infringer was the patentee.

claims.claim: Civil conspiracy to breach the license agreement
claims.legal_basis: State civil conspiracy law requiring an underlying tort, premised on alleged conspiracy to breach the patent license agreement
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held civil conspiracy cannot be based solely on a breach of contract without an independent underlying tort.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks standing to sue for patent infringement because it is only a licensee and the patentee is a necessary party
defenses.legal_basis: Patent standing doctrine requiring that only patentees or exclusive licensees with all substantial rights may sue; general rule that a licensee must join the patent owner as plaintiff

defenses.defense: Civil conspiracy claim fails because it is based only on breach of contract, not an independent tort
defenses.legal_basis: State law requirement that civil conspiracy must be grounded in an underlying tort, not merely a contractual breach

case_id: 2025-04-03_USCOURTS-jpml-1_24-F-03143_IN RE_ OpenAI_ Inc._ Copyright Infringement Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re OpenAI Inc. Copyright Infringement Litigation
ai_relevance: Dispute concerns alleged copyright infringement from using copyrighted works to train large language models (LLMs) such as GPT-4, and consolidation of these AI-training lawsuits in one court for coordinated pretrial proceedings.
ai_presence:
"…alleging copyright infringement related to their use of copyrighted works without consent for training large language models (LLMs) like GPT-4."
"…stemming from the use of copyrighted materials in training AI models…"
"…like books and articles, to teach its robot how to talk and answer questions."
"…sharing information, like how this robot was taught."

parties.plaintiff_description: Authors and rightsholders suing over AI training
parties.defendant_description: AI developer and technology corporation defendants

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on use of copyrighted works to train LLMs such as GPT-4 without consent or authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (unauthorized reproduction and use of copyrighted works).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits; actions ordered centralized in the Southern District of New York for coordinated pretrial proceedings.

claims.claim: Related copyright-adjacent and statutory claims arising from alleged misuse of copyrighted materials in AI training (e.g., derivative works, distribution, or similar theories).
claims.legal_basis: Related federal and possibly state copyright and statutory causes of action associated with training and operation of AI models.
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits; included within the group of actions transferred to the Southern District of New York for coordinated pretrial proceedings.

claims.claim: Procedural request/opposition regarding whether the multiple copyright actions should be centralized in a single district for pretrial purposes.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1407 (multidistrict litigation centralization standard: common questions of fact, convenience, and efficiency).
claims.outcome: Court granted centralization and ordered transfer of all related actions to the Southern District of New York for coordinated pretrial proceedings despite some plaintiffs’ objections.

defenses.defense: Opposition to centralization based on alleged differences among plaintiffs’ claims and factual circumstances, arguing separate handling is preferable.
defenses.legal_basis: Argument under 28 U.S.C. § 1407 that actions lack sufficient common factual questions or that centralization would not promote convenience and efficiency.

case_id: 2019-11-27_USCOURTS-cand-4_19-cv-04433_Demos v. Google et al.pdf
case_name: Demos v. Google et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges defendants misuse AI products to create monopolies and engage in anticompetitive conduct, forming part of the claimed antitrust violations.
ai_presence: The summary states that the plaintiff alleged “antitrust violations, including the misuse of artificial intelligence (AI) products” and claimed that “these companies have created monopolies and engaged in numerous antitrust activities” through such conduct.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual prisoner bringing antitrust lawsuit
parties.defendant_description: Various high-tech and oil corporations

claims.claim: Defendants engaged in antitrust violations by misusing artificial intelligence products to create and maintain monopolies and otherwise restrain trade.
claims.legal_basis: Federal antitrust law (e.g., Sherman Act and related antitrust principles requiring harm to competition).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice for lack of antitrust standing and speculative, non-curable allegations.

claims.claim: Defendants’ collective conduct as high-tech and oil companies constituted numerous unspecified antitrust activities that harmed the plaintiff.
claims.legal_basis: General federal antitrust law requiring antitrust injury and harm to competition.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court found no antitrust injury, no harm to competition, and no plausible facts that could cure the deficiencies.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks antitrust standing because alleged injuries do not constitute antitrust injury or harm to competition.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust standing doctrine under federal antitrust law requiring injury of the type the antitrust laws were intended to prevent.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s allegations are speculative and conclusory, failing to state a plausible antitrust claim.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and plausibility requirement from Twombly/Iqbal.

case_id: 2022-11-28_USCOURTS-cofc-1_21-cv-01295_ALJINDI v. USA.pdf
case_name: Aljindi v. United States
ai_relevance: Plaintiff’s claimed intellectual property involved scientific work on Information Security, Artificial Intelligence, and Legacy Information Systems allegedly used by the federal government without authorization.
ai_presence: The summary states that the plaintiff claimed infringement of intellectual property "specifically related to scientific work on Information Security, Artificial Intelligence (AI), and Legacy Information Systems (LIS)."

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual alleging IP infringement by government
parties.defendant_description: Federal government of the United States

claims.claim: The federal government infringed his intellectual property related to scientific work on Information Security, Artificial Intelligence, and Legacy Information Systems.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under federal copyright law (seeking protection for his scientific work).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a plausible claim; court held he sought copyright protection for uncopyrightable ideas, concepts, and principles.

claims.claim: Request for summary judgment in his favor on the alleged copyright infringement.
claims.legal_basis: Motion for summary judgment under the Rules of the Court of Federal Claims.
claims.outcome: Denied as futile because the underlying complaint failed to state a claim and was dismissed.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s allegations seek copyright protection for ideas, concepts, principles, and discoveries rather than protectable expression.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright law excludes ideas, procedures, processes, systems, and discoveries from protection; failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted (RCFC 12(b)(6)).

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s complaint does not allege sufficient facts to state a plausible claim of copyright infringement against the United States.
defenses.legal_basis: Plausibility pleading standard under federal law (e.g., Twombly/Iqbal) applied through RCFC 12(b)(6).

case_id: 2019-05-07_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_18-cv-07246_CCC Intelligent Solutions Inc v. Tractable Inc..pdf
case_name: CCC Information Services Inc. v. Tractable Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Tractable’s AI system that estimates vehicle repair costs from photos, allegedly built using fraudulently obtained access to CCC’s proprietary CCC ONE estimating software and data.
ai_presence: The case summary explains that Tractable uses artificial intelligence to generate real-time cost estimates from pictures of vehicle damage, in contrast to CCC’s CCC ONE product, which requires physical inspection by human appraisers. Tractable allegedly accessed CCC’s proprietary CCC ONE software and data through fraudulent means to benefit its AI-driven estimating system.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation providing auto-claims estimating software and services
parties.defendant_description: Corporation offering AI-based vehicle damage assessment

claims.claim: Fraudulent access and use of CCC’s proprietary CCC ONE software and data for Tractable’s benefit.
claims.legal_basis: Fraud and unauthorized access to proprietary software and data under contract and common law theories (including misrepresentation and improper use of confidential systems).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this decision; the court addressed only arbitrability and proceeded with litigation in court.

claims.claim: Tractable’s attempt to enforce an arbitration provision based on access obtained through fraud did not bind CCC to arbitrate disputes with Tractable.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law principles governing formation and enforceability of arbitration agreements under the Federal Arbitration Act and state contract law (lack of mutual assent, fraud, and absence of a valid agreement between CCC and Tractable).
claims.outcome: Court held there was no valid arbitration agreement between CCC and Tractable and denied Tractable’s motion to compel arbitration.

defenses.defense: CCC’s claims must be arbitrated because CCC allegedly agreed to arbitrate disputes arising from use of the CCC ONE software, and Tractable may enforce that arbitration agreement.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and contract law doctrines allowing nonsignatories to enforce arbitration agreements (e.g., equitable estoppel, third-party beneficiary, or related theories).

defenses.defense: Any agreement related to CCC ONE’s use extends to disputes involving Tractable’s use, thereby requiring arbitration instead of court litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation and arbitration enforcement principles asserting that the scope of the arbitration clause covers CCC’s claims against Tractable.

case_id: 2019-05-07_USCOURTS-cand-5_18-cv-04327_Lamont v. Conner et al.pdf
case_name: Lamont v. Conner et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges Google misused his confidential information to enhance its AI capabilities after a meeting where trade secrets were disclosed without an NDA.
ai_presence: The summary states that Plaintiff alleged Google misused his trade secrets "to boost its AI capabilities" after a meeting in which confidential information was allegedly shared without an NDA.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual trade secret owner and inventor
parties.defendant_description: Corporate defendants affiliated with Google/Alphabet

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets by Google Ventures and Alphabet Inc. based on alleged misuse of confidential information shared in a meeting without an NDA to enhance Google’s AI capabilities.
claims.legal_basis: Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016 (DTSA) and analogous trade secret principles supporting request for preliminary injunction.
claims.outcome: Court denied Plaintiff’s motion for a preliminary injunction, finding he failed to show a likelihood of success on the merits of his trade secret claims or irreparable harm.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunctive relief to stop Google Ventures and Alphabet Inc. from using or benefiting from the alleged trade secrets related to AI capabilities.
claims.legal_basis: Federal standard for preliminary injunctions (likelihood of success on the merits, irreparable harm, balance of equities, and public interest) applied in the context of DTSA trade secret claims.
claims.outcome: Court denied the motion for preliminary injunction because Plaintiff did not clearly demonstrate a strong likelihood of success on the merits or irreparable harm.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff has not shown a likelihood of success on the merits of his trade secret misappropriation claims, including insufficient evidence that protectable trade secrets existed or were misused by Defendants.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard requiring a clear showing of likelihood of success on the merits; DTSA elements for trade secret misappropriation.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff has not demonstrated irreparable harm that would occur absent an injunction.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard requiring proof of irreparable harm as a prerequisite to injunctive relief.

case_id: 2025-07-01_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-04257_Kemp v. Meta Platforms Inc..pdf
case_name: Kemp v. Meta Platforms Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges Meta’s AI technology intercepted and misused his electronic communications for years.
ai_presence: The summary states that Bobby M. Kemp sued Meta Platforms Inc. “alleging that Meta's AI technology intercepted and misused his electronic communications between 2015 and 2021.” This is the portion of the case describing where AI is mentioned and how it is implicated in the alleged interception and misuse of communications.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual federal prisoner plaintiff
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating social media platforms

claims.claim: Meta’s AI technology intercepted his electronic communications between 2015 and 2021 in violation of the Stored Communications Act.
claims.legal_basis: Stored Communications Act (SCA), 18 U.S.C. §§ 2701 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as barred by res judicata due to prior lawsuit involving same parties and transactional facts and a final judgment on the merits.

claims.claim: Meta unlawfully intercepted his electronic communications using AI technology in violation of the Wiretap Act.
claims.legal_basis: Wiretap Act, 18 U.S.C. §§ 2510 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as barred by res judicata because the same interception allegations were previously litigated and resolved against Kemp.

claims.claim: Meta’s interception and misuse of his electronic communications violated his rights under the Florida Constitution.
claims.legal_basis: Florida Constitution (state constitutional privacy and related protections).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as barred by res judicata, since the claims arose from the same nucleus of facts already decided in a prior case.

defenses.defense: The claims are precluded because they were already litigated and resolved in a prior lawsuit between Kemp and Meta involving the same alleged interception and misuse of communications.
defenses.legal_basis: Res judicata / claim preclusion: same parties, same transactional nucleus of facts, and prior final judgment on the merits (dismissal with prejudice).

case_id: 2020-11-30_USCOURTS-azd-2_20-mc-00039_Spider Labs Limited v. Doe.pdf
case_name: Spider Labs Limited v. John Doe
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on allegedly defamatory online statements about Spider Labs’ AI technology and its performance in business use.
ai_presence: The summary states that John Doe "allegedly made defamatory statements about Spider Labs' AI technology and business practices" and that the anonymous poster claimed "their tech doesn't work as it's supposed to." These references show AI technology as the subject of the allegedly defamatory comments.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation offering AI-related technology services
parties.defendant_description: Anonymous individual online speaker

claims.claim: Defamation based on online statements criticizing Spider Labs’ AI technology and business practices.
claims.legal_basis: State defamation law; standards for unmasking anonymous online speakers consistent with First Amendment protections.
claims.outcome: No prima facie defamation showing; subpoena to identify Doe was quashed and motion for reconsideration was denied.

claims.claim: Request for subpoena to GoDaddy to disclose John Doe’s identity for purposes of pursuing defamation claims.
claims.legal_basis: Procedural rules for third‑party subpoenas; balancing against First Amendment right to anonymous speech.
claims.outcome: Defendant’s motion to quash the subpoena was granted; court denied Spider Labs’ motion for reconsideration and maintained quashing of the subpoena.

defenses.defense: First Amendment right to anonymous online speech protecting Doe’s identity absent a prima facie defamation showing.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution, First Amendment; case law requiring a prima facie case of defamation before unmasking anonymous speakers.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to provide sufficient evidence that the challenged statements were false or defamatory.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive elements of defamation under applicable state law; requirement of prima facie evidence before compelling identification of anonymous speakers.

case_id: 2020-10-21_USCOURTS-laed-2_19-cv-01304_Bertuccelli et al v. Universal City Studios LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Bertuccelli et al. v. Universal City Studios LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs’ experts used AI-based facial recognition analysis to assess visual similarity between the King Cake Baby artwork and defendants’ baby mask, supporting opinions on substantial similarity in the copyright infringement dispute.
ai_presence: The court’s order explains that plaintiffs’ experts, including James T. Berger and Edward R. Griffor, used artificial intelligence–based facial recognition analysis as part of their methodology to compare the plaintiffs’ “King Cake Baby” image with the baby face mask used in defendants’ films. The AI tools were employed to analyze and quantify perceived similarities between the two faces, and the court held that this AI-based expert testimony was admissible and should not be excluded when determining substantial similarity in the copyright case.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artist and his design studio/corporation
parties.defendant_name: Universal City Studios LLC et al.
parties.defendant_description: Film studio and related entertainment companies

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on defendants’ use of a baby face mask in films allegedly copying plaintiffs’ “King Cake Baby” artwork.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, including 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq., requiring proof of ownership and substantial similarity between protected expression and accused work.
claims.outcome: Ongoing on the merits; in this order, the court allowed plaintiffs’ expert testimony (including AI-based facial recognition analysis) on substantial similarity and denied defendants’ motion to exclude those experts.

claims.claim: Use of expert testimony, including AI-based facial recognition analysis, to demonstrate substantial similarity between the King Cake Baby image and the movie mask.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Evidence 702 and Daubert standards governing admissibility of expert testimony in copyright substantial similarity analysis.
claims.outcome: Court held both experts (Berger and Griffor) are qualified, their methodologies sufficiently reliable and relevant, and denied defendants’ motion to exclude their testimony.

defenses.defense: Challenge to admissibility and reliability of plaintiffs’ expert testimony on similarity, including AI-based facial recognition analysis.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Evidence 702 and Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals standards for expert qualification, reliability, and relevance.

defenses.defense: Implicit contention that any similarity between the baby mask and King Cake Baby is not substantial or is otherwise non-infringing (e.g., based on general ideas or unprotectable elements).
defenses.legal_basis: Substantial similarity doctrine under federal copyright law; protection limited to original expression, not ideas or unprotectable features.

case_id: 2024-11-14_USCOURTS-txwd-1_24-cv-00354_Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves alleged infringement of patents covering artificial intelligence features in Meta’s augmented and virtual reality systems, including AI-controlled characters and behaviors in virtual environments.
ai_presence: The summary describes that several of Mullen’s asserted patents relate to “artificial intelligence (AI)” and that Mullen alleges Meta’s augmented and virtual reality systems infringe these AI-related patents. Meta moved to dismiss claims tied to these AI patents, arguing that Mullen’s complaint did not plausibly or specifically explain how Meta’s products use AI in the manner claimed by the patents. The court agreed in part, recommending dismissal with prejudice of Counts II and VII, which concerned AI usage and wireless telephone functionality, because Mullen’s allegations about AI were too conclusory and lacked sufficient factual detail to state a plausible claim of infringement.

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding business entity asserting infringement
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation offering AR and VR systems

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s augmented and virtual reality systems allegedly practicing Mullen’s patented wireless telephone functionality.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 relating to wireless telephone–related patent claims (Count II).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court found allegations implausible and insufficiently specific, and denied further amendment as futile.

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s use of artificial intelligence features in its AR/VR systems allegedly covered by Mullen’s AI-related patent claims.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 relating to AI-focused patent claims (Count VII).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court held AI infringement allegations lacked plausibility and specificity, and refused leave to amend as futile.

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s AR/VR products allegedly using patented “landscape characteristics” in virtual playfields and environments.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 relating to patents covering landscape characteristics and virtual playfields (remaining counts other than II and VII).
claims.outcome: Allowed to proceed; motion to dismiss denied as to these counts, with issues reserved for further claim construction.

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s AR/VR systems allegedly infringing additional asserted patents beyond those specifically tied to AI and wireless telephones.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 for the remainder of the twelve asserted patents not dismissed.
claims.outcome: Allowed to proceed; court declined to dismiss these claims at the pleading stage.

defenses.defense: Mullen’s complaint fails to plausibly allege that Meta’s products practice the claimed wireless telephone functionality.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 8 and 12(b)(6) requiring a plausible claim for patent infringement.

defenses.defense: Mullen’s AI-related infringement allegations are conclusory and lack specific facts showing how Meta’s AR/VR systems use AI as claimed in the patents.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 8 and 12(b)(6) plausibility requirement for patent infringement complaints.

defenses.defense: The concept of “landscape characteristics” and related claim elements are not adequately tied to specific accused features in Meta’s products in some asserted patents.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6) challenge to sufficiency and specificity of infringement allegations, particularly regarding claim elements like “landscape characteristics.”

defenses.defense: Further amendment of the complaint would be futile because prior amendments failed to cure pleading deficiencies in the AI and wireless telephone counts.
defenses.legal_basis: Standard for denying leave to amend under Fed. R. Civ. P. 15(a) when amendment would be futile.

case_id: 2025-03-18_USCOURTS-caDC-23-05233_Stephen Thaler v. Shira Perlmutter_ et al.pdf
case_name: Thaler v. Perlmutter
ai_relevance: Dispute over whether an AI system (“Creativity Machine”) can be an author under the Copyright Act and obtain copyright registration for its output.
ai_presence: The case centers on an artwork created by Dr. Stephen Thaler’s AI system, the “Creativity Machine.” Thaler sought to register a copyright in this AI-generated artwork, listing the machine as the sole author. The U.S. Copyright Office denied the application based on its human-authorship requirement, and both the district court and appellate court held that the AI system, as a non-human, cannot be recognized as an author under the Copyright Act of 1976.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual AI developer and copyright applicant
parties.defendant_description: U.S. Copyright Office officials and related government actors

claims.claim: Challenge to denial of copyright registration for AI-generated artwork listing the AI as sole author.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act of 1976; administrative review of U.S. Copyright Office refusal to register; argument that the Act permits non-human authorship or ownership via human claimant.
claims.outcome: Rejected. District court and appellate court upheld the Copyright Office’s denial, holding that the Copyright Act requires human authorship and the AI cannot be an author.

claims.claim: Assertion that the U.S. Copyright Office’s human-authorship requirement is inconsistent with the Copyright Act and unlawfully excludes AI-generated works.
claims.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of the Copyright Act of 1976; challenge to agency’s longstanding human-authorship policy as contrary to law.
claims.outcome: Rejected. The appellate court affirmed that the Act mandates human authorship and that the Office’s human-authorship requirement is lawful and consistent with the statute.

defenses.defense: Only human beings can be “authors” under the Copyright Act, so a work created solely by an AI system is ineligible for registration.
defenses.legal_basis: Text, structure, and history of the Copyright Act of 1976; longstanding judicial precedent and Copyright Office practice requiring human authorship.

defenses.defense: The Copyright Office properly denied registration because the application listed a non-human AI (“Creativity Machine”) as the sole author, with no human author identified.
defenses.legal_basis: Registration standards and regulations administered by the U.S. Copyright Office under the Copyright Act; agency’s authority to refuse applications that do not meet statutory requirements.

case_id: 2025-01-29_USCOURTS-txwd-1_24-cv-00354_Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves alleged patent infringement by Meta’s AR/VR products, including claims that they use artificial intelligence in ways covered by Mullen’s patents; AI-related infringement claim (Count VII) was dismissed for insufficient factual allegations.
ai_presence: The summary states that Mullen Industries LLC asserted patents “related to augmented and virtual reality technologies” and that “Counts II and VII which involved claims about wireless telephones and artificial intelligence” were dismissed. The court found that “the AI aspects … were deemed insufficiently detailed” and that Mullen failed to provide “plausible allegations that Meta's products met essential claim elements” for the AI-related patent claim in Count VII. Thus, AI is mentioned in connection with a specific patent count alleging that Meta’s AR/VR technologies use artificial intelligence in an infringing manner, but the court held the AI-related pleadings were inadequate and dismissed that count with prejudice.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate patent holder and plaintiff entity
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation; AR/VR product developer

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s AR/VR technologies allegedly practicing Mullen’s patented inventions (general infringement claims proceeding under Counts I, III, IV, V, and IX).
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law, 35 U.S.C. § 271 (direct and/or indirect infringement of asserted patents).
claims.outcome: Meta’s motion to dismiss denied as to Counts I, III, IV, V, and IX; these patent infringement claims were allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Patent infringement alleging Meta’s accused AR/VR products qualify as “wireless telephones” and infringe a patent directed to wireless telephone technology (Count II).
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law, 35 U.S.C. § 271, based on a patent whose claims require a “wireless telephone.”
claims.outcome: Meta’s motion to dismiss granted with prejudice as to Count II; the court held Mullen failed to plausibly allege that Meta’s AR/VR products meet the “wireless telephone” claim limitation, so Count II was dismissed and cannot be repleaded.

claims.claim: Patent infringement alleging Meta’s AR/VR products use artificial intelligence in a manner covered by Mullen’s AI-related patent (Count VII).
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law, 35 U.S.C. § 271, based on a patent with essential claim elements involving artificial intelligence functionality.
claims.outcome: Meta’s motion to dismiss granted with prejudice as to Count VII; the court found Mullen’s AI-related allegations were insufficiently detailed and did not plausibly show that Meta’s products satisfied the AI claim elements, so the AI-based infringement claim was dismissed and cannot be refiled.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim because the accused AR/VR products cannot plausibly be considered “wireless telephones,” so they do not meet an essential claim limitation of the asserted patent in Count II.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) (failure to state a claim); patent infringement pleading standards requiring plausible allegations that each claim element is met.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim because Mullen did not plead sufficient factual detail showing that Meta’s AR/VR products practice the artificial intelligence elements required by the asserted AI-related patent in Count VII.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) (failure to state a claim); Twombly/Iqbal plausibility standard for patent infringement complaints requiring non-conclusory factual allegations for each claim element.

defenses.defense: General Rule 12(b)(6) challenge to the sufficiency of Mullen’s infringement allegations across all asserted counts, arguing that Mullen had not adequately pled that Meta’s AR/VR products satisfy all essential elements of the asserted patent claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and federal pleading standards for patent infringement (Twombly/Iqbal).

case_id: 2014-09-18_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_13-cv-04417_Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC et al.
ai_relevance: The patent covers an expert system, a type of artificial intelligence, used to evaluate equipment operator impairment and control equipment based on that assessment. The dispute centers on how to construe the AI-related term “expert system(s)” in the patent for purposes of infringement.
ai_presence: The case summary describes the patented invention as an “Expert System Safety Screening of Equipment Operators.” It explains that the term “expert system(s)” is “a type of artificial intelligence used to evaluate the impairment of equipment operators and control equipment based on that assessment.” The court’s construction defines “expert system(s)” in the ’392 patent as a computer program that includes: “(1) a database module with information pertinent to assessing operator impairment; (2) a decision module for applying logic to screen and control the equipment; and (3) an interface module connecting with equipment and operators.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate patent owner and licensor
parties.defendant_description: Automotive manufacturers accused of patent infringement

claims.claim: Infringement of U.S. Patent No. 7,394,392 relating to an expert system for safety screening of equipment operators by Mercedes-Benz USA and Daimler AG.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 based on alleged use of systems falling within the construed term “expert system(s)” in the ’392 patent.
claims.outcome: At the claim-construction stage, the court construed “expert system(s)” to mean a computer program including (1) a database module with information pertinent to assessing operator impairment, (2) a decision module for applying logic to screen and control the equipment, and (3) an interface module connecting with equipment and operators; the ultimate infringement determination is not resolved in the provided summary.

defenses.defense: Non‑infringement based on a narrower interpretation of “expert system(s)” that would exclude defendants’ accused systems.
defenses.legal_basis: Argument that, under proper claim construction principles (intrinsic evidence, specification, and prosecution history), the term “expert system(s)” should be limited such that defendants’ products do not meet all claim limitations.

case_id: 2021-03-29_USCOURTS-prd-3_19-cv-01690_Mech-Tech College_ LLC et al v. Friger-Salgueiro et al.pdf
case_name: Artificial Intelligence, Corp. v. Osvaldo Oscar Friger Salgueiro et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED
ai_presence: The plaintiff is named Artificial Intelligence, Corp. The court notes that the involvement of AI in the case does not relate to the content of the lawsuit itself but is instead only the name of the plaintiff corporation; no artificial intelligence technology is at issue in the dispute.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation owning copyrighted TV review capsules
parties.defendant_name: Osvaldo Oscar Friger Salgueiro; Friger Entertainment, LLC
parties.defendant_description: Individual YouTuber and his entertainment company

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged unauthorized copying, uploading, and commercial exploitation of AIC’s television review capsules on YouTube.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act of 1976, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to Osvaldo Oscar Friger Salgueiro; the court found AIC alleged sufficient facts to plausibly state a copyright infringement claim against him, so the claim proceeds.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement claim asserted against Friger Entertainment, LLC for alleged involvement in the same unauthorized use and monetization of AIC’s review capsules on YouTube.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act of 1976, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted as to Friger Entertainment, LLC; claims against the company dismissed for failure to allege sufficient facts showing its involvement in the infringement.

defenses.defense: Friger Entertainment, LLC was not involved in the alleged infringing acts and therefore cannot be held liable for copyright infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); lack of factual allegations tying the LLC to the alleged infringement under the Copyright Act.

defenses.defense: The complaint does not plead sufficient specific facts to plausibly show that Mr. Friger’s use of the review capsules constitutes actionable copyright infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6) and plausibility standard under Twombly/Iqbal for claims under the Copyright Act of 1976.
